item.A: adv. on or toward the rear of a ship E.G. The passengers moved abaft of the ship so as to escape the fire in the front of the ship.

v. [abandoned; abandoned; abandoning] to leave behind; to give something up E.G. After failing for several years, he abandoned his dream of starting a grocery business. Lucy embarked on her new adventure with abandon.

v. [abased; abased; abasing] to degrade; humiliate E.G. The mother's public reprimand abased the girl. The insecure father, after failing to achieve his own life-long goals, abased his children whenever they failed.
v. [abbreviated; abbreviated; abbreviating] to shorten; compress E.G. His vacation to Japan was abbreviated when he acquired an illness treatable only in the United States.
v. [abdicated; abdicated; abdicating] to reject, renounce, or abandon E.G. Due to his poor payment record, it may be necessary to abdicate our relationship with the client.

adj. abnormal; straying from the normal or usual path E.G. The aberrant flight pattern of the airplane alarmed the air traffic controllers. His aberrant behavior led his friends to worry the divorce had taken its toll.
n. a state of temporary suspension or inactivity E.G. Since the power failure, the town has been in abeyance.

v. [abhorred; abhorred; abhorring] to hate E.G. By the way her jaw tensed when he walked in, it is easy to see that she abhors him. The dog abhorred cats, chasing and growling at them whenever he had the opportunity.
adj. of the worst or lowest degree E.G. The Haldemans lived in abject poverty, with barely a roof over their heads.
v. [abjured; abjured; abjuring] to give up E.G. The losing team may abjure to the team that is winning.
n. a denial E.G. The woman's abnegation of her loss was apparent when she began to laugh.

v. [abominated; abominated; abominating] to loathe; to hate E.G. Randall abominated all the traffic he encountered on every morning commute. Please do not abominate the guilty person until you hear the complete explanation.
v. [abridged; abridged; abridging] to shorten; to limit E.G. The editor abridged the story to make the book easier to digest.
v. [abrogated; abrogated; abrogating] to cancel by authority E.G. The judge would not abrogate the law.
adj. happening or ending unexpectedly E.G. The abrupt end to their marriage was a shock to everyone.
v. [absconded; absconded; absconding] to go away hastily or secretly; to hide E.G. The newly wed couple will abscond from the reception to leave on the honeymoon.

v. [absolved; absolved; absolving] to forgive; to acquit E.G. The judge will absolve the person of all charges. After feuding for many years, the brothers absolved each other for the many arguments they had.

adj. sparing in use of food or drinks E.G. If we become stranded in the snow storm, we will have to be abstemious with our food supply. In many abstemious cultures the people are so thin due to the belief that too much taken into the body leads to contamination of the soul.

n. the act or process of voluntarily refraining from any action or practice; self-control E.G. In preparation for the Olympic games, the athletes practiced abstinence from red meat and junk food, adhering instead to a menu of pasta and produce.
adj. hard to understand; deep E.G. The topic was so abstruse the student was forced to stop reading. The concept was too abstruse for the average student to grasp.
adj. very deep E.G. The abysmal waters contained little plant life.
v. [acceded; acceded; acceding] to comply with; to consent to E.G. With defeat imminent, the rebel army acceded to hash out a peace treaty.
n. loud approval; applause E.G. Edward Albee's brilliantly written Broadway revival of A Delicate Balance received wide acclaim.
n. approving or praising mention; a sign of approval or respect E.G. Rich accolades were bestowed on the returning hero. Accolades flowed into her dressing room following the opening-night triumph.
n. [accomplices] co-conspirator; partner E.G. The bank robber's accomplice drove the get- away car.

n. growth by addition; a growing together by parts E.G. With the accretion of the new members, the club doubled its original size. The addition of the new departments accounts for the accretion of the company.

v. [accrued; accrued; accruing] a natural growth; a periodic increase E.G. Over the course of her college career, she managed to accrue a great deal of knowledge. The savings were able to accrue a sizable amount of interest each year. During his many years of collecting stamps, he was able to accrue a large collection of valuable items.

adj. tasting sour; harsh in language or temper E.G. Too much Bay Leaf will make the eggplant acerbic. The baby's mouth puckered when she was given the acerbic medicine. The columnist's acerbic comments about the First Lady drew a strong denunciation from the President.

v. [acquiesced; acquiesced; acquiescing] to agree without protest E.G. The group acquiesced to the new regulations even though they were opposed to them. After a hard-fought battle, the retailers finally acquiesced to the draft regulations.

adj. sharp; bitter E.G. Although the soup is a healthy food choice, it is so acrid not many people choose to eat it. The fire at the plastics factory caused an acrid odor to be emitted throughout the surrounding neighborhood.
n. sharpness or bitterness in language or manner. E.G. The acrimony of her response was shocking.
n. an old saying now accepted as being truthful E.G. The adage do unto others as you wish them to do unto you is still widely practiced.

adj. not yielding, firm E.G. After taking an adamant stand to sell the house, the man called the real estate agency. The girl's parents were adamant about not allowing her to go on a dangerous backpacking trip.
adj. rotten E.G. The egg will become addled if it is left unrefrigerated.
adj. skilled; practiced E.G. The skilled craftsman was quite adept at creating beautiful vases and candleholders.
v. [adjured; adjured; adjuring] solemnly ordered E.G. The jurors were adjured by the judge to make a fair decision.
adj. expert or skillful E.G. The repair was not difficult for the adroit craftsman. The driver's adroit driving avoided a serious accident.
n. praise in excess E.G. The adulation was in response to the heroic feat. The adulation given to the movie star was sickening.
v. [adulterated; adulterated; adulterating] to corrupt, debase, or make impure E.G. The dumping of chemicals will adulterate the pureness of the lake.
n. [adversaries] an enemy; foe E.G. The peace treaty united two countries that were historically great adversaries.
adj. negative; hostile E.G. Contrary to the ski resort's expectations, the warm weather generated adverse conditions for a profitable weekend.
v. to plead in favor of E.G. Amnesty International advocates the cause for human rights. Martin Luther King, Jr. was a great advocate of civil rights.

adj. of beauty; pertaining to taste in art and beauty E.G. She found that her aesthetic sense and that of the artist were at odds. His review made one wonder what kind of aesthetic taste the critic had.
adj. friendly; amiable E.G. Her affable puppy loved to play with children.
v. [affiliated; affiliated; affiliating] to connect or associate with; to accept as a member E.G. The hiking club affiliated with the bird-watching club.
n. [affinities] a connection; similarity of structure E.G. There is a strong emotional affinity between the two siblings. It turns out that the elements bear a strong affinity to each other.
v. [aggrandized; aggrandized; aggrandizing] to make more powerful E.G. The king wanted to aggrandize himself and his kingdom.
adj. astonished; amazed E.G. Stockholders were aghast at the company's revelation. The landlord was aghast at his water bill.
adj. of the land E.G. Many agrarian people are poor.

n. eager readiness or speed E.G. The manager was so impressed by the worker's alacrity; he suggested a promotion. On the first day of her new job, the recent college graduate was able to leave early after completing all of her tasks with alacrity.
n. a person who studies chemistry E.G. The alchemist's laboratory was full of bottles and tubes of strange looking liquids.
n. [alchemies] any mysterious change of substance or nature E.G. The magician used alchemy to change the powder into a liquid.
n. [allegories] a symbolic description E.G. The book contained many allegories on Russian history.
v. [alleviated; alleviated; alleviating] to lessen or make easier E.G. The airport's monorail alleviates vehicular traffic.
v. [allocated; allocated; allocating] set aside; designate E.G. There have been front row seats allocated to the performer's family. The farmer allocated three acres of his fields to corn.

v. [alluded; alluded; alluding] to refer indirectly to something E.G. The story alludes to part of the author's life. Without stating that the defendant was an ex-convict, the prosecutor alluded to the fact by mentioning his length of unemployment.
v. [allured; allured; alluring] to attract; to entice E.G. The romantic young man allured the beautiful woman by preparing a wonderful dinner. Singapore's allure is its bustling economy.
n. [allusions] an indirect reference (often literary); a hint E.G. The mention of the pet snake was an allusion to the man's sneaky ways. In modern plays allusions are often made to ancient drama.
adj. distant in interest; reserved E.G. Even though the new coworker was aloof, we attempted to be friendly. The calm defendant remained aloof when he was wrongly accused of fabricating his story.
n. [altercations] controversy; dispute E.G. A serious altercation caused the marriage to end in a bitter divorce.

n. unselfish devotion to the welfare of others E.G. After the organization aided the catastrophe victims, it was given an award for altruism. She displayed such altruism by giving up all of her belongings and joining a peace corps in Africa.
adj. unselfish E.G. The altruistic volunteer donated much time and energy in an effort to raise funds for the children's hospital.

n. a mixture or combination (often of metals) E.G. The art display was an amalgam of modern and traditional pieces. That ring is made from an amalgam of minerals; if it were pure gold it would never hold its shape.

v. [amalgamated; amalgamated; amalgamating] to mix, merge, combine E.G. If the economy does not grow, the business may need to amalgamate with a rival company. The three presidents decided to amalgamate their businesses to build one strong company.

v. [amassed; amassed; amassing] to collect together; accumulate E.G. Over the years the sailor has amassed many replicas of boats. The women amassed a huge collection of priceless diamonds and pearls.
adj. not clear; uncertain E.G. The ambiguous law did not make a clear distinction between the new and old land boundary.
adj. undecided E.G. The ambivalent jury could not reach a unanimous verdict.

v. [ameliorated; ameliorated; ameliorating] to improve or make better E.G. A consistent routine of exercise has shown to ameliorate health. We can ameliorate the flooding problem by changing the grading.
n. [amendments] a positive change E.G. The amendment in his ways showed there was still reason for hope.
adj. friendly E.G. The newcomer picked the most amiable person to sit next to during the meeting.
ad. wrong; awry E.G. Seeing that his anorak was gone, he knew something was amiss. Its new muffler aside, the car was behaving amiss.
n. friendly relations E.G. The amity between the two bordering nations put the populations at ease.
adj. with no shape; unorganized E.G. The amorphous gel seeped through the cracks. The amorphous group quickly got lost. The scientist could not determine the sex of the amorphous organism.
v. to put money into a fund at fixed intervals E.G. The couple was able to amortize their mortgage sooner than they thought.

n. something out of place in time (e.g., an airplane in 1492) E.G. The editor recognized an anachronism in the manuscript where the character from the 1500s boarded an airplane. He realized that the film about cavemen contained an anachronism when he saw a jet cut across the horizon during a hunting scene.

n. [analogies] similarity; correlation E.G. The teacher used an analogy to describe the similarities between the two books. Comparing the newly discovered virus with one found long ago, the scientist made an analogy between the two organisms.
n. an allergic reaction E.G. The boy's severe anaphylaxis to a series of medications made writing prescriptions a tricky proposition.

n. [anarchists] one who believes that a formal government is unnecessary E.G. The yell from the crowd came from the anarchist protesting the government. The anarchist attempted to overthrow the established democratic government of the new nation and reinstate chaos and disarray.
n. [anchorages] something that can be relied on E.G. Knowing the neighbors were right next door was an anchorage for the elderly woman.
n. [anecdotes] a short account of happenings E.G. The speaker told an anecdote about how he lost his shoes when he was young.
n. [animosities] a feeling of hatred or ill will E.G. Animosity grew between the two feuding families.
v. [anointed; anointed; anointing] to crown; ordain E.G. A member of the monarchy was anointed by the king.

n. [anomalies] an oddity, inconsistency; a deviation from the norm E.G. An anomaly existed when the report listed one statistic, and the spokeswoman reported another. In a parking lot full of Buicks, Chevys, and Plymouths, the Jaguar was an anomaly.
adj. nameless; unidentified E.G. Not wishing to be identified by the police, he remained anonymous by returning the money he had stolen by sending it through the mail.
n. [antagonisms] hostility; opposition E.G. The antagonism was created by a misunderstanding. The rebellious clan captured a hostage to display antagonism to the new peace treaty.
n. [antipathies] a strong dislike or repugnance E.G. Her antipathy for large crowds convinced her to decline the invitation to the city. The vegetarian had an antipathy toward meat.
n. lack of emotion or interest E.G. He showed apathy when his relative was injured. The disheartened peasants expressed apathy toward the new law which promised new hope and prosperity for all.
adj. pertaining to a discovery or new revelation E.G. Science-fiction movies seem to relish apocalyptic visions.
adj. counterfeit; of doubtful authorship or authenticity E.G. The man who said he was a doctor was truly apocryphal.
v. [appeased; appeased; appeasing] to satisfy; to calm E.G. A milk bottle usually appeases a crying baby.

adj. suitable; apt E.G. Discussion of poverty was apposite to the curriculum, so the professor allowed it. Without reenacting the entire scenario, the situation can be understood if apposite information is given.
adj. fearful; aware E.G. The nervous child was apprehensive about beginning a new school year.
adj. approving or sanctioning E.G. The judge showed his acceptance in his approbatory remark.
adj. suitable (as land) for plowing E.G. When the land was deemed arable the farmer decided to plow.
n. one who is authorized to judge or decide E.G. The decision of who would represent the people was made by the arbiter.
adj. based on one's preference or judgment E.G. Rick admitted his decision had been arbitrary, as he claimed no expertise on the matter.

adj. obscure; secret E.G. With an arcane expression, the young boy left the family wondering what sort of mischief he had committed. The wizard's description of his magic was purposefully arcane so that others would be unable to copy it.

n. original pattern or model; prototype E.G. This man was the archetype for scores of fictional characters. The scientist was careful with the archetype of her invention so that once manufacturing began, it would be easy to reproduce it.
adj. with passionate or intense feelings E.G. The fans' ardent love of the game kept them returning to watch the terrible team.
adj. laborious, difficult; strenuous E.G. Completing the plans for the new building proved to be an arduous affair. Building a house is arduous work, but the result is well worth the labor.
adj. extremely dry, parched; barren, unimaginative E.G. The terrain was so arid that not one species of plant could survive. Their thirst became worse due to the arid condition of the desert.
adj. having a smell which is sweet or spicy E.G. The aromatic smell coming from the oven made the man's mouth water.
adj. acting superior to others; conceited E.G. After purchasing his new, expensive sports car, the arrogant doctor refused to allow anyone to ride with him to the country club.
v. [arrogated; arrogated; arrogating] to claim or demand unduly E.G. The teenager arrogated that he should be able to use his parent's car whenever he desired.

v. to utter clearly and distinctly E.G. It's even more important to articulate your words when you're on the phone. You didn't have to vote for him to agree that Adlai Stevenson was articulate. A salesperson must be articulate when speaking to a customer.
n. [artifices] skill in a craft E.G. The artifice of glass-making takes many years of practice.
n. one who leads a simple life of self-denial E.G. The monastery is filled with ascetics who have devoted their lives to religion. The nuns lead an ascetic life devoted to the Lord.
adj. germ free E.G. It is necessary for an operating room to be aseptic.
adv. a sideways glance of disapproval E.G. The look askance proved the guard suspected some wrongdoing.
n. [asperities] harshness E.G. The man used asperity to frighten the girl out of going. The asperity of the winter had most everybody yearning for spring.

n. slanderous statement; a damaging or derogatory criticism E.G. The aspersion damaged the credibility of the organization. He blamed the loss of his job on an aspersion stated by his co-worker to his superior.
n. [aspirants] a person who goes after high goals E.G. The aspirant would not settle for assistant director--only the top job was good enough.
n. [assays] to determine the quality of a substance. E.G. Have the soil assayed.
v. [assessed; assessed; assessing] to estimate the value of E.G. She assessed the possible rewards to see if the project was worth her time and effort.

adj. carefully attentive; industrious E.G. It is necessary to be assiduous if a person wishes to make the most of his time at work. He enjoys having assiduous employees because he can explain a procedure once and have it performed correctly every time.
v. [assuaged; assuaged; assuaging] to relieve; ease E.G. Medication should assuage the pain. The medication helped assuage the pain of the wound.

n. a substance that contracts bodily tissues E.G. After the operation an astringent was used on his skin so that the stretched area would return to normal. The downturn in sales caused the CEO to impose astringent measures. Her astringent remarks at the podium would not soon be forgotten.
adj. cunning; sly E.G. The astute lawyer's questioning convinced the jury of the defendant's guilt.

v. [atrophied; atrophied; atrophying] to waste away, as from lack of use; to wither E.G. A few months after he lost his ability to walk, his legs began to atrophy. The atrophy of the muscles was due to the injury.
v. [attenuated; attenuated; attenuating] to thin out; to weaken E.G. Water is commonly used to attenuate strong chemicals. The chemist attenuated the solution by adding water.
adj. something that is abnormal E.G. The atypical behavior of the wild animal alarmed the hunters.
adj. fearless; bold E.G. The audacious soldier went into battle without a shield.
v. [augmented; augmented; augmenting] to increase or add to; to make larger E.G. They needed more soup so they augmented the recipe. They were able to augment their savings over a period of time.
adj. to be imposing or magnificent E.G. The palace was august in gold and crystal.
adj. being of a good omen; successful E.G. It was auspicious that the sun shone on the first day of the trip. The campaign had an auspicious start, foreshadowing the future.
adj. having a stern look; having strict self-discipline E.G. The old woman always has an austere look about her. The austere teacher assigned five pages of homework each day.
adj. real; genuine E.G. An authentic diamond will cut glass.
n. acting as a dictator E.G. The authoritarian made all of the rules but did none of the work. Fidel Castro is reluctant to give up his authoritarian rule.

n. [autocracies] an absolute monarchy; government where one person holds power E.G. The autocracy was headed by a demanding man. She was extremely power-hungry and therefore wanted her government to be an autocracy.
n. an absolute ruler E.G. The autocrat in charge of the government was a man of power and prestige. The autocrat made every decision and divided the tasks among his subordinates.
n. inordinate desire for gaining and possessing wealth E.G. The man's avarice for money kept him at work through the evenings and weekends. The avarice of the president led to his downfall.
v. [averred; averred; avering] to affirm as true E.G. The witness was able to aver the identity of the defendant.
ad. crooked(ly); uneven(ly) E.G. Hearing the explosion in the laboratory, the scientist realized the experiment had gone awry.
adj. the clear blue color of the sky E.G. The azure sky made the picnic day perfect.
adj. harmful, malign, detrimental E.G. After she was fired, she realized it was a baleful move to point the blame at her superior. The strange liquid could be baleful if ingested.

adj. trite; without freshness or originality E.G. Attending parties became trite after a few weeks. It was a banal suggestion to have the annual picnic in the park, since that was where it had been for the past five years.
adj. deadly or causing distress, death E.G. Not wearing a seat belt could be baneful.
adj. extravagant; ornate E.G. The baroque artwork was made up of intricate details which kept the museum-goers enthralled. The baroque furnishings did not fit in the plain, modest home.
n. a fortified place or strong defense E.G. The strength of the bastion saved the soldiers inside of it.
v. [battened; battened; battening] to gain E.G. The team could only batten by drafting the top player.
n. a showy yet useless thing E.G. The woman had many baubles on her bookshelf.
v. [begot; begotten, begot; begetting] to bring into being E.G. The king wished to beget a new heir.
adj. indebted to E.G. The children were beholden to their parents for the car loan.
v. [behooved; behooved; behooving] to be advantageous; to be necessary E.G. It will behoove the students to buy their textbooks early.
v. [belittled; belittled; belittling] to make small; to think lightly of E.G. The unsympathetic friend belittled her friend's problems and spoke of her own as the most important.
adj. quarrelsome; warlike E.G. The bellicose guest would not be invited back again.
v. [bemused; bemused; bemusing] to preoccupy in thought E.G. The girl was bemused by her troubles.
n. [benefactors] one who helps others; a donor E.G. An anonymous benefactor donated $10,000 to the children's hospital.

adj. conferring benefits; kindly E.G. He is a beneficent person, always taking in stray animals and talking to people who need someone to listen. A beneficent donation helped the organization meet its goal.
adj. kind; generous E.G. The professor proved a tough questioner, but a benevolent grader. The benevolent gentleman volunteered his services.
adj. mild; harmless E.G. A lamb is a benign animal, especially when compared with a lion.
v. [berated; berated; berating] scold; reprove E.G. The child was berated by her parents for breaking the china.
v. to be deprived of; to be in a sad manner E.G. The loss of his job will leave the man bereft of many luxuries. The widower was bereft for many years after his wife's death.
v. [besought, beseeched; besought, beseeched; beseeching] to ask earnestly E.G. The soldiers beseeched the civilians for help.
v. [besmirched; besmirched; besmirching] to dirty or discolor E.G. The soot from the chimney will besmirch clean curtains.
adj. having the qualities of a beast; brutal E.G. The bestial employer made his employees work in an unheated room.
v. [betrothed; betrothed; betrothing] to promise or pledge in marriage E.G. The man betrothed his daughter to the prince.
adj. prejudiced; influenced E.G. The vegetarian had a biased opinion regarding what should be ordered for dinner.
adj. happening every two years E.G. The biennial journal's influence seemed only magnified by its infrequent publication. She has lived here for four years and has seen the biennials bloom twice.

adj. pertaining to or affecting both sides or two sides; having two sides E.G. A bilateral decision was made so that both partners reaped equal benefits from the same amount of work. The brain is a bilateral organ, consisting of a left and right hemisphere.

adj. irreligious; away from acceptable standards E.G. The upper-class parents thought that it was blasphemous for their son to marry a waitress. His blasphemous outburst was heard throughout the room.
adj. obvious; unmistakable E.G. The blatant foul was reason for ejection. The defendant was blatant in his testimony.
adj. causing frustration or destruction E.G. The blighted tornado left only one building standing in its wake.
adj. [blither; blithest] happy; cheery E.G. The wedding was a blithe celebration. The blithe child was a pleasant surprise.
v. [boded; boded; boding] to foretell something E.G. The storm bode that we would not reach our destination.
n. pompous speech; pretentious words E.G. After he delivered his bombast at the podium, he arrogantly left the meeting. The presenter ended his bombast with a prediction of his future success.
adj. pompous; wordy E.G. The bombastic woman talks a lot about herself.
n. a rude person E.G. The boor was not invited to the party, but he came anyway.
n. [breadths] the distance from one side to another E.G. The table cloth was too small to cover the breadth of the table.
n. briefness; shortness E.G. On Top 40 AM radio, brevity was the coin of the realm.
adj. mixed with a darker color E.G. In order to get matching paint we made a brindled mixture.
v. [broached; broached; broaching] to introduce into conversation E.G. Broaching the touchy subject was difficult.
adj. abrupt in manner or speech E.G. His brusque answer was neither acceptable nor polite.
adj. having to do with shepherds or the country E.G. The bucolic setting inspired the artist.
adj. arrogant E.G. He was bumptious in manner as he approached the podium to accept his anticipated award.
n. a clumsy person E.G. The one who broke the crystal vase was a true bungler.
v. [burgeoned; burgeoned; burgeoning] to grow or develop quickly E.G. The tumor appeared to burgeon more quickly than normal. After the first punch was thrown, the dispute burgeoned into a brawl.

v. [burlesqued; burlesqued; burlesquing] to imitate in a non-serious manner E.G. His stump speeches were so hackneyed, he seemed to be burlesquing of his role as a congressman. George Burns was considered one of the great practitioners of burlesque.
adj. [burlier; burliest] strong; bulky E.G. The lumberjack was a burly man.
v. [burnished; burnished; burnishing] to polish by rubbing E.G. The vase needed to be burnished to restore its beauty.
n. a group of persons joined by a secret E.G. The very idea that there could be a cabal cast suspicion on the whole operation.

n. stockpile; store E.G. The town kept a cache of salt on hand to melt winter's snow off the roads. Extra food is kept in the cache under the pantry. The cache for his jewelry was hidden under the bed.
adj. sounding jarring E.G. The cacophonous sound from the bending metal sent shivers up our spines.

n. [cacophonies] a harsh, inharmonious collection of sounds; dissonance E.G. The beautiful harmony of the symphony was well enjoyed after the cacophony coming from the stage as the orchestra warmed up. The amateur band created more cacophony than beautiful sound.

v. [cajoled; cajoled; cajoling] to coax with insincere talk E.G. To cajole the disgruntled employee, the manager coaxed him with lies and sweet talk. The salesman will cajole the couple into buying the stereo.
n. [calamities] disaster E.G. The fire in the apartment building was a great calamity.
n. quality E.G. The caliber of talent at the show was excellent.
adj. being young or immature E.G. With the callow remark the young man demonstrated his age. Although the girl could be considered an adult, the action was very callow.
n. [calumnies] slander E.G. I felt it necessary to speak against the calumny of the man's good reputation.
n. a false statement or rumor E.G. The canard was reported in a scandalous tabloid.
adj. honest; truthful E.G. People trust her because she's so candid.

n. insincere or hypocritical statements of high ideals; the jargon of a particular group or occupations E.G. The theater majors had difficulty understanding the cant of the computer scientists. The remarks by the doctor were cant and meant only for his associates.

n. [caprices] a sudden, unpredictable or whimsical change E.G. The caprice with which the couple approached the change of plans was evidence to their young age. The king ruled by caprice as much as law.
adj. changeable; fickle E.G. The capricious bride-to-be has a different church in mind for her wedding every few days.
adj. disposed to find fault E.G. A captious attitude often causes difficulties in a relationship.
n. unlimited authority E.G. The designer was given carte blanche to create a new line for the fall.

n. [cascades] waterfall E.G. The hikers stopped along the path to take in the beauty of the rushing cascade. The water cascaded down the rocks into the pool. He took a photograph of the lovely cascade. The drapes formed a cascade down the window.
v. [castigated; castigated; castigating] to punish through public criticism E.G. The mayor castigated the police chief for the rash of robberies.
n. an extreme natural force E.G. The earthquake has been the first cataclysm in five years.
n. anything which creates a situation in which change can occur E.G. The low pressure system was the catalyst for the nor'easter.
n. [catharses] a purging or relieving of the body or soul E.G. He experienced a total catharsis after the priest absolved his sins. Admitting his guilt served as a catharsis for the man.

adj. eating away at; sarcastic words E.G. The caustic chemicals are dangerous. The girl harmed her mother with her caustic remarks. His caustic sense of humor doesn't go over so well when people don't know what they're in for.
v. [caviled, cavilled; caviled, cavilled; caviling, cavilling] to bicker E.G. The children are constantly caviling.
v. [censored; censored; censoring] to examine and delete objectionable material E.G. The children were allowed to watch the adult movie only after it had been censored.

n. [censures] a disapproval; an expression of disapproval E.G. His remarks drew the censure of his employers. A censure of the new show upset the directors. Her parents censured her idea of dropping out of school.
adj. very formal or proper E.G. The black-tie dinner was highly ceremonious.
n. [cessations] ceasing; a stopping E.G. The cessation of a bad habit is often difficult to sustain.
v. [chafed; chafed; chafing] to annoy, to irritate; to wear away or make sore by rubbing E.G. His constant teasing chafed her. He doesn't wear pure wool sweaters because they usually chafe his skin.
n. banter; teasing E.G. The king was used to his jesters good-natured chaffing.

n. a feeling of embarrassment due to failure or disappointment E.G. To the chagrin of the inventor, the machine did not work. She turned red-faced with chagrin when she learned that her son had been caught shoplifting.
n. [charismata, charism] appeal; magnetism E.G. She has such charisma that everyone likes her the first time they meet her.
n. a person who pretends to have knowledge; an impostor E.G. The charlatan deceived the townspeople. It was finally discovered that the charlatan sitting on the throne was not the real king.
adj. [charier; chariest] cautious; being sparing in giving E.G. Be chary when driving at night. The chary man had few friends.
adj. [chaster; chastest] virtuous; free of obscenity E.G. Because the woman believed in being chaste, she would not let her date into the house.
v. [chastised; chastised; chastising] to punish; discipline E.G. The dean chastised the first-year student for cheating on the exam.
v. [cherished; cherished; cherishing] to feel love for E.G. The bride vowed to cherish the groom for life.
n. [chicaneries] trickery or deception E.G. The swindler was trained in chicanery. A news broadcast is no place for chicanery.
n. [chimeras] an impossible fancy E.G. Perhaps he saw a flying saucer, but perhaps it was only a chimera.
adj. cranky; cantankerous E.G. The choleric man was continually upset by his neighbors. Rolly becomes choleric when his views are challenged.
v. [chortled; chortled; chortling] to make a gleeful, chuckling sound E.G. The chortles emanating from the audience indicated it wouldn't be as tough a crowd as the stand-up comic had expected.
n. crude or surly behavior; behavior of a peasant E.G. The fraternity's churlishness ran afoul of the dean's office. The churlishness of the teenager caused his employer to lose faith in him.

n. a roundabout or indirect way of speaking; not to the point E.G. The man's speech contained so much circumlocution that I was unsure of the point he was trying to make. The child made a long speech using circumlocution to avoid stating that it was she who had knocked over the lamp.

adj. being too long, as in a description or expression; a roundabout, indirect, or ungainly way of expressing something E.G. It was a circumlocutory documentary that could have been cut to half its running time to say twice as much.
adj. considering all circumstances E.G. A circumspect decision must be made when so many people are involved.
n. [citadels] a fortress set up high to defend a city E.G. A citadel sat on the hill to protect the city below.
adj. secret E.G. The clandestine plan must be kept between the two of us!
n. [clemencies] mercy toward an offender; mildness E.G. The governor granted the prisoner clemency. The weather's clemency made for a perfect picnic.
n. a parliamentary procedure to end debate and begin to vote E.G. Cloture was declared as the parliamentarians readied to register their votes.

adj. too sugary; too sentimental or flattering E.G. After years of marriage the husband still gave cloying gifts to his wife. Complimenting her on her weight loss, clothing and hairstyle was a cloying way to begin asking for a raise.
v. [coagulated; coagulated; coagulating] to become a semisolid, soft mass; to clot E.G. The liquid will coagulate and close the tube if left standing.
v. [coalesced; coalesced; coalescing] to grow together E.G. The bride and groom coalesced their funds to increase their collateral. At the end of the conference the five groups coalesced in one room.

n. [codas] in music, a concluding passage E.G. By the end of the coda, I was ready to burst with excitement over the thrilling performance. The audience knew that the concerto was about to end when they heard the orchestra begin playing the coda.
v. [coddled; coddled; coddling] to treat with tenderness E.G. A baby needs to be coddled.

v. [codified; codified; codifying] to organize laws or rules into a systematic collection E.G. The laws were codified by those whom they affected. The intern codified all the city's laws into a computerized filing system.
n. [coffers] a chest where money or valuables are kept E.G. The coffer that contained the jewels was stolen.

adj. to the point; clear E.G. The lawyer makes compelling and cogent presentations, which evidently help him win 96 percent of his cases. He made a short, cogent speech which his audience easily understood.

v. [cogitated; cogitated; cogitating] to think hard; ponder E.G. It is necessary to cogitate on decisions which affect life goals. The room was quiet while every student cogitated during the calculus exam.
adj. having the same family E.G. English and German are cognate languages. The woman was a cognate to the royal family.

adj. possessing the power to think or meditate; meditative E.G. Cognitive thought makes humans adaptable to a quickly changing environment. Once the toddler was able to solve puzzles, it was obvious that her cognitive abilities were developing.
adj. aware of; perceptive E.G. She became alarmed when she was cognizant of the man following her. It was critical to establish whether the defendant was cognizant of his rights.
adj. sticking together; connected E.G. The course was a success due to its coherent information. If he couldn't make a coherent speech, how could he run for office?
n. the act of holding together E.G. The cohesion of the group increased as friendships were formed. The cohesion of different molecules forms different substances.
n. a group; band E.G. The cohort of teens gathered at the athletic field.
v. [collaborated; collaborated; collaborating] to work together; cooperate E.G. The two builders collaborated to get the house finished.

adj. having to do with conversation; informal speech E.G. The colloquial reference indicated the free spirit of the group. When you listen to the difference between spoken colloquial conversation and written work, you realize how good an ear a novelist must have to write authentic dialogue.
n. secret agreement for an illegal purpose E.G. The authority discovered a collusion between the director and treasurer.
n. beauty; attractiveness in appearance or behavior E.G. The comeliness of the woman attracted everyone's attention.
v. [commiserated; commiserated; commiserating] to show sympathy for E.G. The hurricane victims commiserated about the loss of their homes.
adj. spacious and convenient; roomy E.G. The new home was so commodious that many new pieces of furniture needed to be purchased.
adj. shared or common ownership E.G. The communal nature of the project made everyone pitch in to help.
adj. in agreement with; harmonious E.G. When repairing an automobile, it is necessary to use parts compatible with that make and model.

adj. content; self-satisfied E.G. The CEO worries regularly that his firm's winning ways will make it complacent. The candidate was so complacent with his poll numbers that he virtually stopped campaigning.
n. the quality of being agreeable or eager to please E.G. The complaisance of the new assistant made it easy for the managers to give him a lot of work without worrying that he may complain.
adj. complying; obeying E.G. Compliant actions should be reinforced. The slave was compliant with every order to avoid being whipped.
v. [comported; comported; comporting] fitting in E.G. It was easy to comport to the new group of employees.
adj. all-inclusive; complete E.G. It's the only health facility around to offer comprehensive care.

v. [compromised; compromised; compromising] to settle by mutual adjustment E.G. Labor leaders and the automakers compromised by agreeing to a starting wage of $16 an hour in exchange for concessions on health-care premiums.
v. [conceded; conceded; conceding] to acknowledge; admit E.G. After much wrangling, the conceded that the minister had a point. Satisfied with the recount, the mayor conceded graciously.
n. [conceits] an exaggerated personal opinion E.G. The man's belief that he was the best player on the team was pure conceit.
n. an attempt to make friendly or placate E.G. The attempt at conciliation.
adj. to reconcile E.G. The diplomat sought to take a conciliatory approach to keep the talks going.
adj. in few words; brief E.G. The concise instructions were printed on two pages rather than the customary five.
n. any private meeting or closed assembly E.G. The conclave was to meet in the executive suite.
v. [condescended; condescended; condescending] to come down from one's position or dignity E.G. The arrogant, rich man was usually condescending towards his servants.
v. [condoned; condoned; condoning] to overlook; to forgive E.G. The loving and forgiving mother condoned her son's life of crime I will condone your actions of negligence.
n. [confluences] a thing which is joined together E.G. Great cities often lie at the confluence of great rivers.
v. [confounded; confounded; confounding] to lump together, causing confusion; to damn E.G. The problem confounded our ability to solve it. Confound you, you scoundrel!
n. a collection or mixture of various things E.G. The conglomeration is made up of four different interest groups. The soup was a conglomeration of meats and vegetables.
v. [conjoined; conjoined; conjoining] to combine E.G. The classes will conjoin to do the play.
v. [conjured; conjured; conjuring] to call upon or appeal to; to cause to be, appear, come E.G. The smell of the dinner conjured images of childhood. The magician conjured a rabbit out of a hat.
n. secret cooperation in wrongdoing E.G. With the guard's connivance, the convict was able to make his escape.
n. [connoisseurs] expert; authority (usually refers to a wine or food expert) E.G. They allowed her to choose the wine for dinner since she was the connoisseur.

adj. containing associated meanings in addition to the primary one E.G. Along with the primary meaning of the word, there were two connotative meanings. The connotative meaning of their music was spelled out in the video.
v. [consecrated; consecrated; consecrating] to declare sacred; to dedicate E.G. We will consecrate the pact during the ceremony. The park was consecrated to the memory of the missing soldier.
adj. following as an effect; important E.G. His long illness and consequential absence set him behind in his homework. The decision to move the company will be consequential to its success.
n. [consorts] a companion, spouse E.G. An elderly woman was seeking a consort. They waited until dark to consort under the moonlight.
adj. easy to see; noticeable E.G. The diligent and hardworking editor thought the obvious mistake was conspicuous.
n. amazement or terror that causes confusion E.G. The look of consternation on the child's face caused her father to panic.

v. [constrained; constrained; constraining] to force, compel; to restrain E.G. It may be necessary to constrain the wild animal if it approaches the town. The student was constrained to remain in her seat until the teacher gave her permission to leave.
n. the completion; finish E.G. Following the consummation of final exams, most of the students graduated.
adj. living or happening at the same time; modern E.G. Contemporary furniture will clash with your traditional sectional.
n. scorn; disrespect E.G. The greedy, selfish banker was often discussed with great contempt.
adj. quarrelsome E.G. The contentious student was asked to leave the classroom. They hate his contentious behavior because every suggestion they give ends in a fight.
v. to attempt to disprove or invalidate E.G. I will attempt to contest the criminal charges against me.
adj. touching; or adjoining and close, but not touching E.G. There are many contiguous buildings in the city because there is no excess land to allow space between them.

v. [contravened; contravened; contravening] to act contrary to; to oppose or contradict E.G. The story of the accused contravened the story of the witness. The United Nations held that the Eastern European nation had contravened the treaty.
adj. regretful; sorrowful E.G. Regretting his decision not to attend college, the contrite man did not lead a very happy life. A contrite heart has fixed its wrongs.
adj. resisting authority E.G. The man was put in jail for contumacious actions.
n. a bruise; an injury where the skin is not broken E.G. The man was fortunate to receive only contusions from the crash.
n. a puzzle or riddle E.G. I spent two hours trying to figure out the conundrum. The legend says that to enter the secret passageway, one must answer the ancient conundrum.

adj. traditional; common E.G. The bride wanted a conventional wedding ceremony, complete with white dresses, many flowers, and a grand reception party. Conventional telephones are giving way to videophones.

v. [converged; converged; converging] to move toward one point (opposite: diverge) E.G. It was obvious that an accident was going to occur as the onlookers watched the two cars converge. The two roads converge at the corner.
n. a fondness for festiveness or joviality E.G. His conviviality makes him a welcome guest at any social gathering.
v. [convoked; convoked; convoking] a call to assemble E.G. The teacher convoked her students in the auditorium to help prepare them for the play.
adj. abundant; in great quantities E.G. Her copious notes touched on every subject presented in the lecture.
n. obesity E.G. The corpulence of the man kept him from fitting into the seat.
v. [correlated; correlated; correlating] to bring into mutual relation E.G. The service man was asked to correlate the two computer demonstration pamphlets.
v. [corroborated; corroborated; corroborating] to confirm the validity E.G. The witness must corroborate the prisoner's story if she is to be set free.

n. a clique; a group who meet frequently, usually socially E.G. A special aspect of campus life is joining a coterie. Every day after school she joins her coterie on the playground and they go out for a soda.
n. [covenants] a binding and solemn agreement E.G. With the exchange of vows, the covenant was complete.

adj. greedy; very desirous E.G. Lonnie, covetous of education, went to almost every lecture at the university. Covetous of her neighbor's pool, she did everything she could to make things unpleasant..
v. [cowered; cowered; cowering] to huddle and tremble E.G. The lost dog cowered near the tree. The tellers cowered in the corner as the bandit ransacked the bank.
adj. [coyer; coyest] modest; bashful E.G. Her coy manners attracted the man. He's not really that shy, he's just being coy.

adj. [crasser; crassest] stupid or dull; insensitive E.G. To make light of someone's weakness is crass. They made their money the old-fashioned way, but still they were accused of being crass. My respect for the man was lowered when he made the crass remark.
n. [cravens] coward; abject person E.G. While many fought for their rights, the craven sat shaking, off in a corner somewhere. Craven men will not stand up for what they believe in.
adj. deserving blame; guilty E.G. The convicted criminal still denies that he is culpable for the robbery.
n. [curbs] a restraint or framework E.G. A curb was put up along the street to help drainage.
n. an ill-tempered person E.G. The curmudgeon asked the children not to play near the house.
adj. hasty; slight E.G. The detective's cursory examination of the crime scene caused him to overlook the lesser clues.
n. one who believes that others are motivated entirely by selfishness. E.G. The cynic felt that the hero saved the man to become famous.
n. a raised platform at one end of a room E.G. The dais was lowered to make the speaker look taller.
v. [dallied; dallied; dallying] to loiter; to waste time E.G. Please do not dally or we will miss our appointment.
adj. [danker; dankest] damp and chilly E.G. The cellar became very dank during the winter time.
adj. fearless; not discouraged E.G. The dauntless ranger scaled the mountain to complete the rescue.
n. scarcity; shortage E.G. A series of coincidental resignations left the firm with a dearth of talent. The dearth of the coverage forced him to look for a new insurance agent.
n. disaster; collapse E.G. The Securities and Exchange Commission and the stock exchanges implemented numerous safeguards to head off another debacle on Wall Street.
v. [debased; debased; debasing] to make lower in quality E.G. The French are concerned that Franglais, a blending of English and French, will debase their language.
n. [debaucheries] indulgence in one's appetites E.G. The preacher decried debauchery and urged charity.

v. [debilitated; debilitated; debilitating] to enfeeble; to wear out E.G. The phlebitis debilitated him to the point where he was unable even to walk. The illness will debilitate the muscles in his legs.
adj. having an affable manner; carefree E.G. Opening the door for another is a debonair action.
n. a decline in morals or art E.G. Some believe the decadence of Nero's rule led to the fall of the empire.
adj. shedding; temporary E.G. When the leaves began to fall from the tree we learned that it was deciduous.
n. an act of being firm or determined E.G. Decisiveness is one of the key qualities of a successful executive.

adj. showing decorum; propriety, good taste E.G. This movie provides decorous refuge from the violence and mayhem that permeates the latest crop of Hollywood films. The decorous suit was made of fine material.
v. [decried; decried; decrying] to denounce or condemn openly E.G. The pastor decried all forms of discrimination against any minority group.
n. to harm a name or reputation; to slander E.G. The carpenter felt that the notoriousness of his former partner brought defamation to his construction business.
n. a yielding of opinion; courteous respect for E.G. To avoid a confrontation, the man showed deference to his friend. The deference shown to the elderly woman's opinion was heartwarming.

adj. yielding to the opinion of another E.G. After debating students living in the Sixth Ward for months, the mayor's deferential statements indicated that he had come to some understanding with them.
adj. no longer living or existing E.G. The man lost a large sum of money when the company went defunct.

v. [deigned; deigned; deigning] condescend; stoop E.G. He said he wouldn't deign to dignify her statement with a response. Fired from his job as a programmer analyst, Joe vowed he would never deign to mop floors-even if he were down to his last penny.
adj. harmful; hurtful E.G. Deleterious fumes escaped from the overturned truck.

v. [deliberated; deliberated; deliberating] to consider carefully; weigh in the mind E.G. The jury deliberated for three days before reaching a verdict. The brother's deliberate attempt to get his sibling blamed for his mistake was obvious to all.
v. [delineated; delineated; delineating] to outline; to describe E.G. She delineated her plan so that everyone would have a basic understanding of it.
v. to dissolve E.G. The snow deliquesced when the temperature rose.
n. [delusions] a false belief or opinion E.G. The historian suffered from the delusion that he was Napoleon.
n. [demises] ceasing to exist as in death E.G. The demise of Gimbels followed years of decline.

v. [demurred; demurred; demurring] to object E.G. She hated animals, so when the subject of buying a cat came up, she demurred. She said yes, but he detected a demur in her voice. She was nominated to sit on the committee, but she demurred. The council president called for a vote, and hearing no demur, asked for a count by the clerk.

v. [denigrated; denigrated; denigrating] to defame, to blacken or sully; to belittle E.G. After finding out her evil secret, he announced it to the council and denigrated her in public. Her attempt to denigrate the man's name was not successful.
v. [denounced; denounced; denouncing] to speak out against; condemn E.G. A student rally was called to denounce the use of drugs on campus.
v. [depicted; depicted; depicting] to portray; describe E.G. The mural depicts the life of a typical urban dweller.
v. [depleted; depleted; depleting] to reduce; to empty, exhaust E.G. Having to pay the entire bill will deplete the family's savings.
n. [depositions] a removal from office or power; a testimony E.G. Failing to act lawfully could result in his deposition. She met with her lawyer this morning to review her deposition.
n. [depravities] moral corruption; badness E.G. Drugs and money caused depravity throughout the once decorous community. The depravity of the old man was bound to land him in jail one day.

v. [deprecated; deprecated; deprecating] to express disapproval of; to protest against E.G. The environmentalists deprecated the paper companies for cutting down ancient forests. The organization will deprecate the opening of the sewage plant.
n. [depredations] a plundering or laying waste E.G. The pharaoh's once rich tomb was empty after centuries of depredation from grave robbers.
v. [derided; derided; deriding] to laugh at with contempt; to mock E.G. No matter what he said, he was derided. It is impolite to deride someone even if you dislike him.
n. [derisions] the act of mocking; ridicule, mockery E.G. A day of derision from the boss left the employee feeling depressed. Constant derision from classmates made him quit school.
adj. showing disrespect or scorn for E.G. The derisive comment was aimed at the man's life long enemy.
adj. belittling; uncomplimentary E.G. He was upset because his annual review was full of derogatory comments.
v. [descanted; descanted; descanting] lengthy talking or writing E.G. The man will descant on the subject if you give him too much speaking time.
v. [desecrated; desecrated; desecrating] to profane; violate the sanctity of E.G. The teenagers' attempt to desecrate the church disturbed the community.
v. [desisted; desisted; desisting] to stop or cease E.G. The judge ordered the man to desist from calling his ex-wife in the middle of the night.
adj. [more desolate; most desolate] to be left alone or made lonely E.G. Driving down the desolate road had Kelvin worried that he wouldn't reach a gas station in time.
v. [despoiled; despoiled; despoiling] to take everything; plunder E.G. The Huns despoiled village after village.
n. [despotisms] tyranny; absolute power or influence E.G. The ruler's despotism went uncontested for 30 years.
adj. poor; poverty-stricken E.G. One Bangladeshi bank makes loans to destitute citizens so that they may overcome their poverty. Many of the city's sections are destitute.
adj. moving in a random, directionless manner E.G. The thefts were occurring in a desultory manner making them difficult to track.
adj. separated; not interested E.G. Detached from modern conveniences, the islanders live a simple, unhurried life.
v. [deterred; deterred; deterring] to prevent; to discourage E.G. He deterred the rabbits by putting down garlic around the garden.
adj. distinct limits E.G. The new laws were very determinate as far as what was allowed and what was not allowed.
adj. lacking; empty E.G. The interplanetary probe indicated that the planet was devoid of any atmosphere.
adj. skillful, quick mentally or physically E.G. The dexterous gymnast was the epitome of grace on the balance beam.

n. a bitter or abusive speech E.G. During the divorce hearings she delivered a diatribe full of the emotion pushing her away from her husband. The diatribe was directed towards a disrespectful supervisor.
n. [dichotomies] a division into two parts or kinds E.G. The dichotomy within the party threatens to split it. The dichotomy between church and state renders school prayer unconstitutional.
n. [dicta, dictums] a formal statement of either fact or opinion E.G. Computer programmers have a dictum: garbage in, garbage out.
adj. instructive; dogmatic E.G. Our teacher's didactic technique boosted our scores. The didactic activist was not one to be swayed.
n. a hesitation in asserting oneself E.G. A shy person may have great diffidence when forced with a problem.
adj. timid; lacking self-confidence E.G. The director is looking for a self-assured actor, not a diffident one. Her diffident sister couldn't work up the courage to ask for the sale.
adj. spread out; verbose (wordy) E.G. The toys were discovered in a diffuse manner after the birthday party. His monologue was so diffuse that all his points were lost.
v. [digressed; digressed; digressing] stray from the subject; wander from topic E.G. It is important to not digress from the plan of action.
n. [dilettantes, dilettanti] an admirer of the fine arts; a dabbler E.G. Though she played the piano occasionally, she was more of a dilettante.
n. hard work E.G. Anything can be accomplished with diligence and commitment.
adj. smaller than average E.G. They lived in a diminutive house. The diminutive woman could not see over the counter.
n. a noise which is loud and continuous E.G. The din of the jackhammers reverberated throughout the concrete canyon.
n. [dints] strength E.G. The dint of the bridge could hold trucks weighing many tons.
n. [dirges] a hymn for a funeral; a song or poem expressing lament E.G. The mourners sang a traditional Irish dirge .
n. disapproval E.G. Her disapprobation of her daughter's fiancee divided the family.
n. (state of) disorder E.G. The thief left the house in disarray.
v. [disavowed; disavowed; disavowing] to deny; to refuse to acknowledge E.G. The actor has disavowed the rumor.

adj. distinguishing one thing from another; having good judgment E.G. He has a discerning eye for knowing the original from the copy. Being discerning about a customer's character is a key qualification for a loan officer.
v. [discomfited; discomfited; discomfiting] to frustrate the expectations of E.G. The close game discomfited the number one player.
n. [discords] disagreement; lack of harmony E.G. There was discord amidst the jury, and therefore a decision could not be made.

v. to converse; to communicate in an orderly fashion E.G. The scientists discoursed on a conference call for just five minutes but were able to solve three major problems. The interviewee discoursed so fluently, she was hired on the spot.
adj. showing good judgment in conduct; prudent E.G. We confided our secret in Mary because we knew she'd be discreet.

adj. separate; individually distinct E.G. There were four discrete aspects to the architecture of the home. The citizens committee maintained that road widening and drainage were hardly discrete issues.

v. [discriminated; discriminated; discriminating] distinguish; demonstrate bias E.G. Being a chef, he discriminated carefully among ingredients. Reeling from the fact that senior managers had been caught on tape making offensive remarks, the CEO said he would not tolerate any of his firm's employees discriminating against anyone for any reason.
n. intense dislike E.G. She showed great disdain toward anyone who did not agree with her. She disdains the very ground you walk upon.
v. [disentangled; disentangled; disentangling] to free from confusion E.G. We need to disentangle ourselves from the dizzying variety of choices.
adj. discouraged; depressed E.G. After failing the exam, the student became disheartened and wondered if he would ever graduate.

adj. not frank or candid; deceivingly simple (opposite: ingenious) E.G. The director used a disingenuous remark to make his point to the student. He always gives a quick, disingenuous response; you never get a straight answer.
adj. neutral; unbiased (alternate meaning E.G. A disinterested person was needed to serve as arbitrator of the argument. He never takes sides; he's always disinterested.

v. [disparaged; disparaged; disparaging] to belittle; undervalue E.G. After she fired him she realized that she had disparaged the value of his assistance. The lawyer will attempt to disparage the testimony of the witness.
adj. unequal; dissimilar E.G. They came from disparate backgrounds, one a real estate magnate, the other a custodian. The disparate numbers of players made the game a sure blowout.
n. [disparities] difference in form, character, or degree E.G. There is a great disparity between a light snack and a great feast.
adj. lack of feeling; impartial E.G. She was a very emotional person and could not work with such a dispassionate employer.
v. [dispersed; dispersed; dispersing] to scatter; separate E.G. The pilots dispersed the food drops over a wide area of devastation. Tear gas was used to disperse the crowd.
adj. argumentative; inclined to disputes E.G. His disputatious streak eventually wore down his fellow parliament members. The child was so disputatious he needed to be removed from the room.

v. [dissembled; dissembled; dissembling] to pretend; to feign E.G. The man dissembled his assets shamelessly to avoid paying alimony. Agent 007 has a marvelous ability to dissemble his real intentions.

v. [disseminated; disseminated; disseminating] to circulate; scatter E.G. He was hired to disseminate newspapers to everyone in the town. The preacher traveled across the country to disseminate his message.
v. [dissented; dissented; dissenting] to disagree; differ in opinion E.G. They agreed that something had to be done, but dissented on how to do it.

n. musical discord; a mingling of inharmonious sounds E.G. Much twentieth-century music is not liked by classical music lovers because of the dissonance it holds and the harmonies it lacks. The dissonance of his composition makes for some rough listening.

adj. not in harmony; in disagreement E.G. Despite several intense rehearsals, the voices of the choir members continued to be dissonant. The dissonant nature of the man's temperament made the woman fearful to approach him with the new idea.
adj. having separations or being reserved E.G. Rolonda's friends have become more distant in recent years.
n. inflation or extension E.G. The bulge in the carpet was caused by the distention of the wood underneath.
v. [dithered; dithered; dithering] to act indecisively E.G. She dithered every time she had to make a decision. Having to take two tests in one day left the student in a dither.

v. [diverged; diverged; diverging] separate, split E.G. The path diverges at the old barn, one fork leading to the house, and the other leading to the pond. The wide, long river diverged into two distinct separate rivers, never again to join.
adj. different; varied E.G. The course offerings were so diverse I had a tough time choosing.
n. being stripped E.G. When it was found the team cheated, there was a divestiture of their crown.
adj. manageable; obedient E.G. We needed to choose a docile pet because we hadn't the patience for a lot of training.
n. [documents] official paper containing information E.G. They needed a written document to prove that the transaction occurred. Facing an audit, she had to document all her client contacts.
n. verse characterized by forced rhyme and meter E.G. Contrary to its appearance, doggerel can contain some weighty messages.
n. [dogmas, dogmata] a collection of beliefs E.G. The dogma of the village was based on superstition.

adj. stubborn; biased E.G. Their dogmatic declaration clarified their position. The dogmatic statement had not yet been proven by science. The student's dogmatic presentation annoyed his classmates as well as his instructor.
adj. as if asleep E.G. The animals lay dormant until the spring thaw.
adj. excessively fond of E.G. With great joy, the doting father held the toddler.
adj. [doughtier; doughtiest] brave and strong E.G. The doughty fireman saved the woman's life.
adj. [dowdier; dowdiest] shabby in appearance E.G. The dowdy girl had no buttons on her coat and the threads were falling apart.
adj. doubtful; uncertain E.G. Many people are dubious about the possibility of intelligent life on other planets. The new information was dubious enough to re-open the case.
n. [duplicities] deception E.G. She forgave his duplicity but divorced him anyway.

n. imprisonment; the use of threats E.G. His duress was supposed to last 10-15 years. The policewoman put the man under duress in order to get a confession. The Labor Department inspector needed to establish whether the plant workers had been held under duress.
adj. [earthier; earthiest] unrefined E.G. The earthy-looking table was bare.
n. an overflowing of high spirits; effervescence E.G. She emanated ebullience as she skipped and sang down the hallway after learning of her promotion.

adj. odd; peculiar E.G. People like to talk with the eccentric artist since he has such different views on everyday subjects. Wearing polka dot pants and a necklace made of recycled bottle tops is considered eccentric.
adj. pertaining or relating to a church E.G. Ecclesiastic obligations include attending mass.
adj. picking from various possibilities; made up of material from various sources E.G. You have eclectic taste. The eclectic collection of furniture did not match.
adj. not wasteful; thrifty E.G. With her economical sense she was able to save the company thousands of dollars.
n. [edifices] a large building E.G. The edifice rose 20 stories and spanned two blocks.

v. [edified; edified; edifying] to build or establish; to instruct and improve the mind E.G. According to their schedule, the construction company will edify the foundation of the building in one week. The teachers worked to edify their students through lessons and discussion.
v. [educed; educed; educing] to draw out; to infer from information E.G. Because she is so dour, I was forced to educe a response. I educe from the report that the experiment was a success.
v. [effaced; effaced; effacing] to erase; to make inconspicuous E.G. Hiding in the woods, the soldier was effaced by his camouflage uniform.
adj. having qualities attributed to a woman; delicate E.G. A high-pitched laugh made the man seem effeminate.
n. liveliness; spirit E.G. Her effervescence was contagious; she made everyone around her happy. The effervescence of champagne is what makes it different from wine.
n. [effigies] the image or likeness of a person E.G. Demonstrators carried effigies of the dictator they wanted overthrown.

n. [effluviums, effluvia] an outflow of vapor of invisible particles; a noxious odor E.G. The effluvium from the exhaust had a bad smell. It was difficult to determine from where the effluvium issued.
n. [effronteries] arrogance E.G. The effrontery of the young man was offensive.
adj. pouring out or forth; overflowing E.G. The effusive currents rush through the broken dam.
adj. self-centered, viewing everything in relation to oneself E.G. The egocentric professor could not accept the students' opinions as valid.
n. a way out; exit E.G. The doorway provided an egress from the chamber.
n. [elaborations] act of clarifying; adding details E.G. The mayor called for an elaboration on the ordinance's first draft.
n. [elegies] a poem of lament and praise for the dead E.G. Upon conclusion of the elegy, the casket was closed.
n. [ellipses] omission of words that would make the meaning clear E.G. The accidental ellipsis confused all those who heard the speech.
n. the ability to speak well E.G. The speaker's eloquence was attributed to his articulate manner of speaking.
v. [elucidated; elucidated; elucidating] to make clear; to explain E.G. In the paper's conclusion, its purpose was elucidated in one sentence.
adj. hard to catch E.G. Even the experienced, old fisherman admitted that the trout in the river were quite elusive.
v. [emanated; emanated; emanating] to emit E.G. Happiness emanates from the loving home.
v. to engage or invest in E.G. The embarkation into self-employment was a new start for the woman.
v. [embellished; embellished; embellishing] to improve by adding details E.G. Adding beads to a garment will embellish it.
n. [eminences] a lofty place; superiority E.G. After toiling in the shadows for years, at last she achieved eminence. The eminence of the institution can be seen in the impact of its research.
adj. softening or soothing to the skin; having power to soften or relax living tissues E.G. When hands become dry, it may be necessary to soothe them with an emollient lotion.
v. [emulated; emulated; emulating] to try to equal or excel E.G. The neophyte teacher was hoping to emulate her mentor.
adj. filled with love and desire E.G. The young couple are enamored with each other.
n. [encomiums, encomia] formal expression of high praise E.G. The sitcom actress gave her co-stars a long encomium as she accepted her Emmy.
v. [encroached; encroached; encroaching] to trespass or intrude E.G. It is unlawful to encroach on another's private property.
v. [encumbered; encumbered; encumbering] to hold back; to hinder E.G. The review of the ethic's committee encumbered the deal from being finalized. A brace will encumber the girl's movement.

adj. native to a particular area; constantly present in a particular country or locality E.G. The endemic fauna was of great interest to the anthropologist. A fast-paced style is endemic to those who live in New York City.
v. [endorsed; endorsed; endorsing] support; to approve of E.G. The entire community endorsed the politician who promised lower taxes and a better school system.
v. [enervated; enervated; enervating] to weaken; to deprive of nerve or strength E.G. The sickness enervates its victims until they can no longer get out of bed.
v. [enfeebled; enfeebled; enfeebling] to make weak E.G. The illness will enfeeble anyone who catches it.

v. [enfranchised; enfranchised; enfranchising] to free from obligation; to admit to citizenship E.G. The player was enfranchised when the deal was called off. The recent immigrants were enfranchised when they took their oath to their new country.
v. [engendered; engendered; engendering] to bring about; beget E.G. The group attempted to engender changes to the law.
v. [enhanced; enhanced; enhancing] to improve; compliment E.G. The new fuel enhanced the performance of the rocket's engines.
n. [enigmas, enigmata] mystery; secret E.G. To all of the searchers, the missing child's location remained a great enigma.
adj. baffling E.G. The enigmatic murder plagued the detective.
n. boredom; apathy E.G. Ennui set in when the children realized they had already played with all the toys.
n. an indefinitely long period of time E.G. The star may have existed for eons.
adj. very short-lived; lasting only a short time E.G. Living alone gave him an ephemeral happiness, soon to be replaced with utter loneliness.
n. a person who has good taste in food and drink E.G. As an epicure, Lance is choosy about the restaurants he visits.
n. [epigrams] a witty or satirical poem or statement E.G. The poet wrote an epigram about the upcoming election.
n. closing section of a play or novel providing further comment. E.G. The epilogue told us the destiny of the characters.
n. an appearance of a supernatural being E.G. The man bowed to the epiphany.
n. [epitaphs] an inscription on a monument; in honor or memory of a dead person E.G. The epitaph described the actions of a brave man.
n. model; typification E.G. The woman chosen to lead the dancers was the epitome of true grace.
n. the quality of remaining calm and undisturbed E.G. Equanimity can be reached when stress is removed from life.
n. [equinoxes] precise time when day and night is of equal length E.G. On the equinox we had twelve hours of night and day.
adj. doubtful; uncertain E.G. Scientific evidence was needed before the equivocal hypothesis was accepted by the doubting researchers.
n. a purposely misleading statement E.G. The equivocations by the man sent the search team looking in the wrong direction.
n. the act of annihilating, destroying, or erasing E.G. Some have theorized that the eradication of the dinosaurs was due to a radical change in climate.
adj. roving in search of adventure E.G. The young man set out across country on an errant expedition.

adj. unpredictable; irregular E.G. His erratic behavior was attributed to the shocking news he had received. The kitten's erratic behavior was attributed to the owner's cruel method of disciplining his pet.
adj. untrue; inaccurate E.G. The reporter's erroneous story was corrected by a new article that stated the truth.
adj. having a wide knowledge acquired through reading E.G. The woman was so erudite, she could recite points on most any subject.
v. [eschewed; eschewed; eschewing] to shun; to avoid E.G. Eschew the traffic and you may arrive on time.
adj. understood by only a chosen few; confidential E.G. The esoteric language was only known by the select group. We have had a number of esoteric conversations.
adj. deserving respect E.G. The estimable hero was given a parade.
adj. very light; airy E.G. The ethereal quality of the music had a hypnotic effect. The dancer wore an ethereal outfit which made her look like an angel.
adj. pertaining to races or peoples and their origin classification, or characteristics E.G. Ethnic foods from five continents were set up on the table.
n. [eulogies] words of praise, especially for the dead E.G. The eulogy was a remembrance of the good things the man accomplished in his lifetime.
n. the use of a word or phrase in place of one that is distasteful E.G. The announcer used a euphemism when he wanted to complain.
n. [euphonies] pleasant combination of sounds E.G. The gently singing birds created a beautiful euphony. The euphony created by the orchestra was due to years of practice.
adj. vanishing quickly; dissipating like a vapor E.G. The evanescent mirage could only be seen at a certain angle.
n. [evasions] the avoiding of a duty E.G. The company was charged with tax evasion, as they did not pay all that they owed.
v. [evoked; evoked; evoking] to call forth; provoke E.G. Seeing her only daughter get married evoked tears of happiness from the mother. Announcement of the results evoked a cheer from the crowd.
v. [exculpated; exculpated; exculpating] to free from guilt E.G. The therapy session will exculpate the man from his guilty feelings.
v. [executed; executed; executing] to put to death; kill E.G. The evil, murderous man was executed for killing several innocent children. I expected him to execute my orders immediately.

adj. serving as an example; outstanding E.G. The honor student's exemplary behavior made him a role model to the younger children. Employees of the month are chosen for their exemplary service to the firm.
adj. thorough; complete E.G. It took an exhaustive effort, using many construction workers, to complete the new home by the deadline.
v. [exhumed; exhumed; exhuming] to unearth; to reveal E.G. The scientists exhumed the body from the grave to test the body's DNA. The next episode will exhume the real betrayer.

adj. a situation calling for immediate attention; needing more than is reasonable E.G. The exigent request for more assistance was answered quickly. The bank seemed to feel that another extension on their loan payment was too exigent a request to honor.
v. [exonerated; exonerated; exonerating] to declare or prove blameless E.G. Hopefully, the judge will exonerate you of any wrongdoing.
adj. going beyond what is reasonable; excessive E.G. Paying hundreds of dollars for the dress is an exorbitant amount.
adj. unusual; striking E.G. Many people asked the name of her exotic perfume. The menu of authentic Turkish cuisine seemed exotic to them, considering they were only accustomed to American food.

adj. convenient in obtaining a result; guided by self-interest E.G. The mayor chose the more expedient path rather than the more correct one. There is no expedient method a teenager will not resort to in order to get the keys to a car of their own.
v. [expedited; expedited; expediting] to hasten the action of E.G. We can expedite the bank transaction if we tell them it is an emergency.
adj. specific; definite E.G. The explicit recipe gave directions for making a very complicated dessert.
n. [expositions] setting forth facts E.G. The exposition by the witness substantiated the story given by the prisoner.
v. [expunged; expunged; expunging] to blot out; to delete E.G. Bleach may be used to expunge the stain.
adj. existing; refers especially to books or documents E.G. Some of my ancestor's letters remain extant.
v. [extemporized; extemporized; extemporizing] to improvise; to make it up as you go along E.G. It was necessary for the musician to extemporize when his music fell off the stand.
v. [extolled; extolled; extolling] to give great praise E.G. The father will extol the success of his son to everyone he meets.
adj. irrelevant; not related E.G. During the long, boring lecture, most people agreed that much of the information was extraneous.
adj. capable of being disentangled E.G. The knots were complicated, but extricable.
n. the act of rejoicing E.G. Exultation was evident by the partying and revelry.
adj. joking in an awkward or improper manner E.G. His facetious sarcasm was inappropriate during his first staff meeting.
v. [facilitated; facilitated; facilitating] make easier; simplify E.G. The new ramp by the door's entrance facilitated access to the building for those in wheelchairs.
n. copy; reproduction E.G. The facsimile of the elaborate painting was indistinguishable from the original.
n. [factions] a number of people in an organization working for a common cause against the main body E.G. A faction of the student body supported the president's view.
adj. misleading E.G. A used car salesman provided fallacious information that caused the naive man to purchase the old, broken car.
adj. liable to be mistaken or erroneous E.G. By not differentiating themselves from the popular band, the group was especially fallible.
n. [fanatics] enthusiast; extremist E.G. The terrorist group was comprised of fanatics who wanted to destroy those who disagreed with them.
adj. difficult to please; dainty E.G. The fastidious girl would not accept any offers as suitable. The woman was extremely fastidious, as evident in her occasional fainting spells.
v. [fathomed; fathomed; fathoming] to understand E.G. It was difficult to fathom the reason for closing the institution. The submarine cruised at 17 fathoms below the surface.
adj. lacking in seriousness; vain and silly E.G. The fatuous prank was meant to add comedy to the situation. His fatuous personality demands that he stop in front of every mirror.
n. [fealties] loyalty E.G. The baron was given land in exchange for his fealty to the king.
adj. reasonable; practical E.G. Increased exercise is a feasible means of weight loss.
adj. productive E.G. The construction crew had a fecund day and were able to leave early.
v. [feigned; feigned; feigning] pretend E.G. It is not uncommon for a child to feign illness in order to stay home from school.
v. [feinted; feinted; feinting] to pretend to throw a punch, as in boxing E.G. The fighter feinted a left hook just before he went for the knockout.
v. to excite or agitate E.G. The rally cry was meant to ferment and confuse the opponent.

v. [ferreted; ferreted; ferreting] to force out of hiding; to search for E.G. The police will ferret the fugitive out of his hiding place. I spent the morning ferreting for my keys I have a pet ferret.
adj. passionate; intense E.G. They have a fervent relationship that keeps them together every minute of every day.
adj. intensely hot; fervent E.G. Her fervid skin alerted the doctor to her fever. The fervid sermon of the preacher swayed his congregation.
n. passion; intensity of feeling E.G. The crowd was full of fervor as the candidate entered the hall.
v. [festered; festered; festering] to become more and more virulent and fixed E.G. His anger festered until no one could change his mind.
adj. having a smell of decay E.G. The fetid smell led us to believe something was decaying in the basement.
n. anything to which one gives excessive devotion E.G. The clay figure of a fertility goddess was a fetish from an ancient civilization.
n. [fetters] a chain to bind the feet E.G. A fetter kept the dog chained to the fence.

adj. changeable; unpredictable E.G. He is quite fickle; just because he wants something today does not mean he will want it tomorrow. Because the man was fickle he could not be trusted to make a competent decision.
n. [fedelities] faithfulness; honesty E.G. His fidelity was proven when he turned in the lost money.
