n. something made up in the mind E.G. The unicorn on the hill was a figment of his imagination.
n. the ability to handle situations with skill and diplomacy E.G. The executor with the most finesse was chosen to meet with the diplomats.
adj. measurable; limited E.G. It was discovered decades ago that the universe is not finite; it has unknown limits which cannot be measured. The finite amount of stored food will soon run out.
n. [fissures] a cleft or crack E.G. The earthquake caused a fissure which split the cliff face.
adj. lacking firmness E.G. The old dog's flaccid tail refused to wag.
v. [flagged; flagged; flagging] to become weak; to send a message E.G. The smaller animal flagged before the larger one.
adj. glaringly wrong E.G. The flagrant foul was apparent to everyone.
adj. being too showy or ornate E.G. The flamboyant nature of the couple was evident in their loud clothing.
n. inexperienced person; beginner E.G. The fledgling mountain climber needed assistance from the more experienced mountaineers. The course was not recommended for fledgling skiers.
v. [flinched; flinched; flinching] wince; drawback E.G. The older brother made his younger sister flinch when he jokingly tried to punch her arm.
adj. talkative; disrespectful E.G. The youngsters were flippant in the restaurant. The teacher became upset with the flippant answer from the student.
v. [flouted; flouted; flouting] to mock or jeer E.G. Do not flout an opponent if you believe in fair play.
n. ability to write easily and expressively E.G. The child's fluency in Spanish and English was remarkable. The immigrant acquired a fluency in English after studying for only two months.
n. a flow; a continual change E.G. With the flux of new students into the school, space was limited.
v. [foisted; foisted; foisting] to falsely identify as real E.G. The smuggler tried to foist the cut glass as a priceless gem.
v. [forayed; forayed; foraying] to raid for spoils, plunder E.G. The soldiers were told not to foray the town.
n. patience; self-restraint E.G. He exhibited remarkable forbearance when confronted with the mischievous children.
adj. pertaining to legal or public argument E.G. The forensic squad dealt with the legal investigation.
adj. something which causes dread or fear E.G. The formidable team caused weak knees in the opponents.
n. firm courage; strength E.G. It is necessary to have fortitude to complete the hike.
adj. happening accidentally E.G. Finding the money under the bush was fortuitous.
v. [fostered; fostered; fostering] encourage; nurture E.G. A good practice routine fosters success. After the severe storm the gardener fostered many of his plants back to health.
adj. rebellious; apt to quarrel E.G. Fractious siblings aggravate their parents.
adj. loaded; charged E.G. The comment was fraught with sarcasm.
adj. frenzied E.G. A frenetic call was made from the crime scene.
v. [fretted; fretted; fretting] to make rough or disturb E.G. The pet will fret the floor if he continues to scratch.
adj. giddiness; lack of seriousness E.G. The hard-working students deserved weekend gatherings filled with frivolity.
adj. not willing to yield or comply with what is reasonable E.G. The executive had to deal with a froward peer who was becoming increasingly difficult.

n. thrift; economical use or expenditure E.G. His frugality limited him to purchasing the item for which he had a coupon. Preparing to save money to send their daughter to college, the parents practiced extreme frugality for several years.

v. [fulminated; fulminated; fulminating] to blame, denunciate E.G. It is impolite to fulminate someone for your mistakes. Senator Shay fulminated against her opponent's double-standard on campaign finance reform.
adj. disgusting due to excess E.G. The man became obese when he indulged in fulsome eating.
adj. [more fundamental; most fundamental] basic; necessary E.G. Shelter is one of the fundamental needs of human existence.
adj. secretive; sly E.G. The detective had much difficulty finding the furtive criminal.
n. pompous talk or writing E.G. The fustian by the professor made him appear arrogant.
adj. worthless; unprofitable E.G. It was a futile decision to invest in that company since they never made any money.
n. a blunder E.G. Calling the woman by the wrong name was a huge gaffe.
v. [gainsaid; gainsaid; gainsaying] to speak against; to contradict E.G. With Senator Bowker the only one to gainsay it, the bill passed overwhelmingly.
v. [galvanized; galvanized; galvanizing] to stimulate as if by electric shock; startle E.G. The pep rally will galvanize the team.
n. a complete range; any complete musical scale E.G. The woman's wardrobe runs the gamut from jeans to suits. His first composition covered the entire gamut of the major scale.
adj. mixed up; distorted or confused E.G. The interference on the phone line caused the data to become garbled on the computer screen.
adj. gaudy, showy E.G. The gold fixtures seemed garish.
v. [garnered; garnered; garnering] to gather up and store; to collect E.G. The squirrels garnered nuts for the winter.
adj. extremely talkative or wordy E.G. No one wanted to speak with the garrulous man for fear of being stuck in a long, one-sided conversation.
adj. awkward; lacking social grace E.G. Unfortunately, the girl was too gauche to fit into high society.
n. [gauntlets] a protective glove E.G. The gauntlet saved the man's hand from being burned in the fire.
adj. common; general E.G. While generic drugs are often a better value, it always a good idea to consult your doctor before purchasing them.
adj. contributing to life; amiable E.G. Key West's genial climate is among its many attractive aspects. Her genial personality made her a favorite party guest.
adj. designating a type of film or book E.G. The genre of the book is historical fiction.
adj. pertinent; related E.G. Her essay contained germane information, relevant to the new Constitutional amendment.
v. [gerrymandered; gerrymandered; gerrymandering] to gain advantage by manipulating unfairly E.G. To gerrymander during negotiations is considered unfair.

v. [gibbered; gibbered; gibbering] to rapidly speak unintelligibly E.G. They did not want him to represent their position in front of the committee since he was prone to gibbering when speaking in front of an audience.
adj. [glibber; glibbest] smooth and slippery; speaking or spoken in a smooth manner E.G. The salesman was so glib that the customers failed to notice the defects in the stereo.
v. [gloated; gloated; gloating] brag; glory over E.G. She gloated over the fact that she received the highest score on the exam, annoying her classmates to no end.
n. [gluttons] overeater E.G. The glutton ate 12 hot dogs.
adj. full of knots; twisted E.G. The raven perched in the gnarled branches of the ancient tree.
n. [goads] a driving impulse E.G. His goad urged him to pursue the object of his affection. Thinking about money will goad him into getting a job.
n. one who eats eagerly E.G. A gourmand may eat several servings of an entree.
adj. magnificent; flamboyant E.G. His grandiose idea was to rent a plane to fly to Las Vegas for the night.
n. seriousness E.G. The gravity of the incident was sufficient to involve the police and the FBI.
adj. fond of the company of others E.G. Gregarious people may find those jobs with human contact more enjoyable than jobs that isolate them from the public.
n. boisterous laughter E.G. A comedian's success is assured when the audience gives forth a guffaw following his jokes.
n. slyness; deceit E.G. By using his guile, the gambler almost always won at the card table.
n. [guises] appearance E.G. The undercover detective, under the guise of friendship, offered to help the drug runner make a connection.
adj. easily fooled E.G. Gullible people are vulnerable to practical jokes.

adj. commonplace; trite E.G. Just when you thought neckties were becoming a hackneyed gift item, along comes the Grateful Dead collection. Have a nice day has become something of a hackneyed expression.

adj. untamed; having a worn look E.G. The lawn in front of the abandoned house added to its haggard look. He looked as haggard as you would expect a new father of quadruplets to look. Just by looking at her haggard features, you can tell she has not slept for many hours.
adj. tranquil; happy E.G. The old man fondly remembered his halcyon days growing up on the farm.
v. [hampered; hampered; hampering] interfere with; hinder E.G. The roadblock hampered their progress, but they knew a shortcut.
adj. disorganized; random E.G. He constantly misplaced important documents because of his haphazard way of running his office.
adj. unlucky; unfortunate E.G. The hapless team could not win a game.
n. [harangues] a lengthy, heartfelt speech E.G. We sat patiently and listened to her harangue. When he finally stopped his haranguing, I responded calmly.

n. [harbors] a place of safety or shelter E.G. We stood at the dock as the ship sailed into the harbor. The peasants were executed for harboring known rebels. The rabbits used the shed as a harbor from the raging storm. Her decision to harbor a known criminal was an unwise one.
adj. having proportionate and orderly parts E.G. The challenge for the new conductor was to mold his musicians' talents into a harmonious orchestra.

adj. [haughtier; haughtiest] proud of oneself and scornful of others E.G. The haughty ways she displayed her work turned off her peers. The haughty girl displayed her work as if she were the most prized artist.
adj. living for pleasure E.G. The group was known for its hedonistic rituals. Hot tubs, good food, and a plethora of leisure time were the hallmarks of this hedonistic society.
v. [heeded; heeded; heeding] obey; yield to E.G. If the peasant heeds the king's commands, she will be able to keep her land.
adj. [heftier; heftiest] heavy or powerful E.G. The unabridged dictionary makes for a hefty book.
n. [heresies] opinion contrary to popular belief E.G. In this town it is considered heresy to want parking spaces to have meters.
n. [heretics] one who holds opinion contrary to that which is generally accepted E.G. Because he believed the world was round, many people considered Columbus to be a heretic.

n. [hiatuses, hiatus] interval; break E.G. Summer vacation provided a much-needed hiatus for the students. Between graduation and the first day of his new job, Tim took a three-month hiatus in the Caribbean.
n. [hierarchies] a system of persons or things arranged according to rank E.G. I was put at the bottom of the hierarchy while Jane was put at the top.
adj. [hoarier; hoariest] whitened by age E.G. The paint had a hoary appearance, as if it were applied decades ago.
n. honor; respect E.G. The police officers paid homage to their fallen colleague with a ceremony that celebrated her life.
n. maintenance of stability E.G. Knowing the seriousness of the operation, the surgeons were concerned about restoring the patient to homeostasis.
n. [homilies] solemn moral talk; sermon E.G. The preacher gave a moving homily to the gathered crowd.

n. something used to sharpen E.G. He ran the knife over the hone for hours to get a razor-sharp edge. The apprenticeship will give her the opportunity to hone her skills. The traveler hones for his homeland.
n. arrogance E.G. Some think it was hubris that brought the president to the point of impeachment.
n. lack of pride; modesty E.G. Full of humility, she accepted the award but gave all the credit to her mentor.
n. [hybrids] anything of mixed origin E.G. The flower was a hybrid of three different flowers.
n. [hyperboles] an exaggeration, not to be taken seriously E.G. The full moon was almost blinding in its brightness, he said with a measure of hyperbole.

adj. two-faced; deceptive E.G. His constituents believed that the governor was hypocritical for calling for a moratorium on negative campaigning while continuing to air some of the most vicious ads ever produced against his opponent. Most of his constituents believed the governor was hypocritical for calling his opponent a mud-slinging hack when his own campaign had slung more than its share of dirt.
adj. assumed; uncertain E.G. A hypothetical situation was set up so we could practice our responses. The professor was good at using hypothetical situations to illustrate complicated theories.

n. one who smashes revered images; an attacker of cherished beliefs E.G. Nietzche's attacks on government, religion, and custom made him an iconoclast of grand dimension. The iconoclast spoke against the traditions of the holiday.

n. [ideologies] speculation; representative way of thinking E.G. His ideology proved to be faulty. The ideology of business can be found in the new book. He joined the religious group because he agreed with their ideology.
n. [idiosyncrasies] any personal peculiarity, mannerism E.G. Her tendency to bite her lip is an idiosyncrasy.
n. [idylls] a written piece of work describing a peaceful rural scene E.G. Reading the idyll made me think of the family farm.
adj. having the nature of fire; volcanic E.G. When the sun shone upon it, the material took on an igneous quality.

adj. ordinary; dishonorable E.G. The king was adamant about keeping his son from wedding an ignoble serf. Consciously lying to someone is ignoble. It was ignoble to disgrace the family in front of all of the townspeople.
adj. contemptible; disgraced E.G. The behavior was so ignominious he was ashamed to be associated with it. She left him because of his ignominious treatment of her.
v. [illuminated; illuminated; illuminating] make understandable E.G. I asked a classmate to illuminate the professor's far-ranging lecture for me.
adj. deceiving, misleading E.G. It was as illusive as a mirage.
adj. unreal; false E.G. He was proven guilty when his alibi was found to be illusory.
v. [imbued; imbued; imbuing] to soak or stain; permeate E.G. The wound will imbue the shirt in blood. The new day imbued him with a sense of optimism.
adj. perfectly clean; correct E.G. An immaculate house is free of dust or clutter.
adj. likely to happen without delay E.G. The storm clouds warned of the imminent downpour.
adj. exempt from or protected against something E.G. Doesn't everybody wish to be immune from the common cold?
adj. unchangeable; permanent E.G. The ties that bind alumni to their university are immutable . The man's immutable schedule soon became boring.
v. [impaled; impaled; impaling] pierce through with, or stick on; something pointed E.G. The knight was impaled by the sharp lance.
adj. unbiased; fair E.G. Exasperated by charges to the contrary, the judge reiterated that he had bent over backwards to be impartial in a case that crackled with emotion.
n. a situation that has no solution or escape E.G. The workers and administration were at an impasse in their negotiations.
adj. showing no emotion E.G. Even when his father died he gave an impassive response and walked out tearless. Her expected announcement was met by an impassive facial expression.
adj. poor; having no money E.G. The Great Depression made family after family impecunious.
v. [impeded; impeded; impeding] to stop the progress of; obstruct E.G. The rain impeded the work on the building.
adj. without regret, shame, or remorse E.G. It was obvious after his impenitent remark to the press that the defendant felt no remorse for his crime.
adj. arrogant; urgent E.G. Her imperious manner cost her her two best friends. It was imperious that the message reach the police chief.
adj. calm; not easily excited E.G. The imperturbable West Point graduate made a fine negotiator.
adj. impenetrable; not allowing anything to pass through E.G. The vest that the policeman wears is impervious to bullets. The child was impervious to the actions of the adult.

adj. moving with great force; done with little thought E.G. The impetuous movement took the art community by storm. The impetuous teenager spent her money without considering what she needed the new purchase for. Dagmar came to regret his impetuous actions, once he realized what he'd done. The pirate's men boarded the ship with impetuous matter-of-factness.
n. [impieties] irreverence toward God; lack of respect E.G. The bishop condemned the impiety of the celebrity's assertions. Impiety is evident in the way many people commit rude actions.

adj. unwilling to be pacified or appeased E.G. The baby was so implacable a warm bottle would not settle her. The two year old was an implacable child; he cried no matter what his parents did to comfort him.
v. to carry into effect E.G. In case of emergency implement the evacuation plan immediately. The rack is an implement of torture.
n. [implications] suggestion; inference E.G. An implication was made that there might be trickery involved.
adj. understood but not plainly stated; without doubt E.G. The child's anger was implicit. Implicit trust must be earned.
adj. unwise; imprudent E.G. If you are planning to invest your money, impolitic decisions may be costly.
v. [imprecated; imprecated; imprecating] to pray for evil; to invoke a curse E.G. A witch may imprecate an enemy with a curse of bad luck.
adj. without preparation E.G. Her impromptu speech was well-received, giving her new confidence in her ability to speak off the cuff.
adj. not providing for the future E.G. An improvident person may end up destitute in latter life.
adj. disrespectful and shameless E.G. Impudent actions caused him to be unpopular.

v. [impugned; impugned; impugning] to attack with words; to question the truthfulness or integrity E.G. The defense lawyer impugned the witness's testimony, which set back the prosecution's case. If I believe the man is a fraud I will impugn his comments.
n. to charge, to attribute a fault or misconduct to another E.G. The imputation of guilt was made by the judge.
adj. not on purpose; unintentional E.G. It was an inadvertent error, to be sure, but nonetheless a mistake that required correction.
adj. to be dull or spiritless; not animated, not endowed with life E.G. The boy nagged his father for a real puppy, not some inanimate stuffed animal.
adj. speechless; unable to speak clearly E.G. He was so inarticulate that he had trouble making himself understood.
adj. not able to be heard E.G. The signals were inaudible when the fans began to cheer.
adj. constant and unending E.G. The mother gave in to the child after her incessant crying. Incessant rain caused the river to flood over its banks.
adj. not yet fully formed; rudimentary E.G. The inchoate building appeared as if it would be a fast-food restaurant. The outline of the thesis was the inchoate form of a very complex theory.
adj. extraneous; unexpected E.G. The defense lawyer argued that the whereabouts of the defendant's sneakers were only incidental to the commission of the crime.
adj. getting to the heart of things; to the point E.G. His incisive questioning helped settle the matter quickly.
adj. apt to; likely E.G. The man's ear for music indicated he was inclined toward learning an instrument. The hillside was inclined just enough to make for a fairly serious climb.
adj. unidentified; disguised E.G. The federal Witness Protection Program makes its charges permanently incognito.
adj. illogical; rambling E.G. Following the accident, the woman went into shock and became incoherent as medics struggled to understand her.
adj. inconvenient E.G. The incommodious illness caused her to miss an important interview.
adj. disagreeing; disharmonious not compatible E.G. Being incompatible with each other, children were assigned to sit on opposite sides of the room.
n. failing to meet necessary requirements E.G. The alleged incompetence of the construction crew would later become the subject of a class-action suit.
adj. not final or of a definite result E.G. The results being inconclusive, the doctors continued to look for a cause of the illness.
adj. not consisting of matter E.G. The apparition appeared to be incorporeal.
adj. not capable of correction or improvement E.G. The mischievous boy was an incorrigible practical joker.
adj. skeptical E.G. The incredulous look on his face led me to believe he was not convinced of its importance. The reporter was incredulous on hearing the computer executive's UFO account.
v. [inculcated; inculcated; inculcating] to impress upon the mind, as by insistent urging E.G. I will inculcate the directions if people are unsure of them.
n. an entry into, especially when not desired E.G. The incursion by enemy forces left the country shocked.
adj. illegible E.G. The scribbling on the paper is indecipherable.
adj. that which cannot be blotted out or erased E.G. The photograph of Neil Armstrong setting foot on the moon made an indelible impression on all who saw it.
v. [indemnified; indemnified; indemnifying] to insure against or pay for loss or damage E.G. It is important to indemnify your valuables with a reliable insurance company.
v. [indicted; indicted; indicting] charge with a crime E.G. The grand jury indicted her and her husband for embezzlement and six other lesser counts.
adj. unconcerned E.G. There he lay, indifferent to all the excitement around him.
n. the condition of being poor E.G. The family's indigence was evident by the run-down house they lived in.
adj. native to a region; inborn or innate E.G. These plants are indigenous to all of the western states. Piranha are indigenous to the tropics.
adj. expressing anger to an injustice E.G. He was indignant over the way he was treated.
adj. lazy; inactive E.G. If we find him goofing off one more time, we won't be able to escape the fact that he's indolent. An indolent student slept all day.
adj. not easily discouraged or defeated E.G. The underdog candidate had an indomitable spirit.
adj. unquestionably; surely E.G. The officer was best indubitably the candidate for captain.
adj. lenient; patient E.G. He has indulgent tendencies to eat chocolate when he is happy.
adj. something inevitable E.G. They were prepared for the ineluctable disaster.
adj. incompetent; clumsy E.G. She would rather update the budget book herself, since her assistant is so inept.
adj. not reacting chemically; inactive E.G. Inert gases like krypton and argon can enhance window insulation.
adj. sure to happen; unavoidable E.G. A confrontation between the disagreeing neighbors seemed inevitable.

adj. having a bad reputation; notorious E.G. After producing machines that developed many problems, the production company became infamous for poor manufacturing. The infamous gang was known for robbery.
n. [infamies] a bad reputation E.G. The town had only 98 residents, so all it took was one bad apple to bring infamy on the whole place.
v. [inferred; inferred; inferring] form an opinion; conclude E.G. From the broad outline he supplied it was easy to infer that the applicant knew a great deal about trains.
adj. clever, resourceful E.G. His ingenious idea made it possible to double production at no extra cost.
n. an unworldly young woman E.G. As an ingenue, Corky had no experience outside of her small town.
adj. noble; honorable E.G. The ingenuous doctor had a great bedside manner, especially when it came to laying out the full implications of an illness.
v. [ingratiated; ingratiated; ingratiating] to bring into one's good graces E.G. The man was hoping to ingratiate himself with his wife by buying a bouquet of flowers and candy.
n. ungratefulness E.G. When she failed to send a thank-you card, her friend took it as a sign of ingratitude .
adj. part of the essential character; intrinsic E.G. A constant smile is inherent in pageant competitors. The inherent desire to do well is present throughout the family.
adj. hostile, unfriendly E.G. The chess player directed an inimical stare at his opponent to knock him off his game.
adj. wicked; unjust E.G. The verbal abuse towards the man was truly iniquitous.

v. [initiated; initiated; initiating] begin; admit into a group E.G. He initiated the dinner discussion by asking his father to borrow the car. As an initiate to the Explorers, George was expected to have a taste for the outdoor life.
adj. natural; inborn E.G. Her talent is wondrous: it hardly matters whether it's innate or acquired. A lion's hunting skills are innate.
adj. harmless; dull E.G. The remark was rude but innocuous. He couldn't bear to sit through another innocuous lecture. The teens engaged in an innocuous game of touch football.
v. [innovated; innovated; innovating] introduce a change; depart from the old E.G. She innovated a new product for the home construction market.
n. [innuendos, innuendoes] an indirect remark; insinuation E.G. The student made an innuendo referring to the professor. The office was rife with innuendo that a takeover was in the works.
adj. eager to ask questions in order to learn E.G. An inquisitive youngster is likely to become a wise adult.
v. [insinuated; insinuated; insinuating] to work into gradually and indirectly E.G. He will insinuate his need for a vacation by saying how tired he has been lately.
adj. uninteresting, boring flat, dull E.G. Many people left the insipid movie before it was finished. Declaring the offerings insipid, the critic grudgingly awarded the restaurant one star.
adj. unable to pay debts E.G. The insolvent state of his bank account kept him from writing any checks.
v. [instigated; instigated; instigating] start; provoke E.G. It was uncertain to the police as to which party instigated the riot.
adj. disobedient to authority E.G. The boy's insubordinate behavior was a constant source of tension between the school and his parents.

adj. having the characteristics of an island; narrow-minded, provincial E.G. After walking along the entire perimeter and seeing that the spit of land was actually insular, we realized it was time to build a boat. His insular approach to education makes him a pariah among liberals.
n. having the characteristics of an island E.G. The insularity of the country made it a great place to build a resort.
adj. incapable of being touched; immaterial E.G. Intangible though it may be, sometimes just knowing that the work you do helps others is reward enough.
v. [interceded; interceded; interceding] to plead on behalf of another; mediate E.G. The superpowers were called on to intercede in the talks between the two warring nations.
adj. periodic; occasional E.G. Luckily, the snow was only intermittent, so the accumulation was slight. The intermittent blinking light was distracting.

adj. stubborn, obstinate; not easily taught or disciplined E.G. Every teacher in the school became frustrated with the intractable student and sent him to the principal's office. An intractable pet can be very frustrating..
adj. uncompromising E.G. With intransigent values, no amount of arguing could change her mind. The baseball owners and players remained intransigent, so a deal was never struck.
adj. fearless, bold E.G. The intrepid photographer flew on some of the fiercest bombing raids of the war. Her intrepid actions deserved a medal.

v. [inundated; inundated; inundating] to flood; to overwhelm with a large amount of E.G. The broken water main inundated the business district with water. Surfing the Internet can inundate you with information: That's why a web browser comes in handy.
adj. accustomed to pain E.G. Beekeepers eventually become inured to bee stings.
adj. a practice settled on over a long period of time E.G. The inveterate induction ceremony bespoke one of the school's great traditions.
v. [invoked; invoked; invoking] ask for; call upon E.G. The parishioners invoked divine help for their troubles.
n. [iotas] a very small piece E.G. There wasn't one iota of evidence to suggest a conspiracy.
adj. prone to anger E.G. The irascible teenager was known to cause fights when upset. Knowing that the king was irascible, the servants decided not to tell him about the broken crystal.
adj. contradictory, inconsistent; sarcastic E.G. Is it not ironic that Americans will toss out leftover French fries while people around the globe continue to starve?
adj. not logical E.G. It would be irrational to climb Mt. Everest without some very warm clothing.
adj. that which cannot be repaired or regained E.G. The damage to the house after the flood was irreparable. The head-on collision left the car irreparable.
adj. without blame or faults E.G. The honesty of the priest made him irreproachable.
n. [itineraries] travel plan; schedule E.G. Their trip's itinerary was disrupted by an unexpected snow storm.
adj. worn-out E.G. A person may become jaded if forced to work too many hours.

n. [jargons] incoherent speech; specialized vocabulary in certain fields E.G. The conversation was nothing but jargon, but then the speakers were nothing but cartoon characters who specialize in an oddly bracing form of gibberish. The engineers' jargon is indecipherable to a layperson.
n. danger; peril E.G. The campers realized they were in potential jeopardy when the bears surrounded their camp.
n. [jesters] a person employed to amuse E.G. The jester tried all of his tricks to get the girl to laugh.
v. [jettisoned; jettisoned; jettisoning] to throw overboard goods to lighten a vehicle; to discard E.G. To raise the balloon above the storm clouds, they had to jettison the ballast.
adj. happy, cheerful, genial, gay E.G. The puppy kept a smile on the jocund boy's face. The jocund atmosphere was due to the team's victory in the playoffs.
n. [jollities] being fun or jolly E.G. The jollity of the crowd was seen in the cheering and laughing.
adj. cheery; jolly E.G. She was a jovial person, always pleasant and fun to be with.
adj. to have or show sound judgment E.G. Because the elder was judicious, the tough decisions were left to him. Putting money away for a rainy day is a judicious decision.
n. [junctures] critical point; meeting E.G. When the gas changed into a liquid, they sensed that they'd come to a critical juncture in their experimentation.
v. [juxtaposed; juxtaposed; juxtaposing] place side-by-side E.G. The author decided to juxtapose the two sentences since they each strengthened the meaning of the other.
v. [kenned, kent; kenned, kent; kenning] to recognize E.G. It was difficult to ken exactly what she had in mind. My ken of the situation proved to be incorrect.
v. [kindled; kindled; kindling] ignite; arouse E.G. Being around children kindled her interest in educational psychology.
n. family relationship; affinity E.G. Living in close proximity increased the kinship of the family.
n. relatives and acquaintances E.G. Our kith will meet at the family reunion.
n. [knaveries] a dishonest act E.G. An act of knavery is cause for loss of trust. The teacher refused to have knavery in his classroom.
v. [kneaded; kneaded; kneading] mix; massage E.G. After mixing the ingredients, they kneaded the dough and set it aside to rise.
adj. [knottier; knottiest] to be puzzling or hard to explain E.G. The mystery was knotty.
n. [labyrinths] maze E.G. Be careful not to get lost in the labyrinth of vegetation.
v. [lacerated; lacerated; lacerating] to tear or mangle; to wound or hurt E.G. Sharp knives may lacerate the skin of an unsuspecting user. Her rejection will lacerate my self-esteem.
adj. sparing of words; terse, pithy E.G. After a laconic introduction the program began. The people enjoyed the public addresses of the laconic queen.

n. [laggards] a person who has fallen behind E.G. The laggard child was lost in the crowd. The train was laggard. Anything can happen in a swim meet: Last year's leader can become this year's laggard.
v. [lambasted; lambasted; lambasting] to scold or beat harshly E.G. If the boy broke the lamp his father will surely lambaste him.
adj. traveling gently over surface; flickering E.G. The lambent flame lit the dark room as the breeze wafted in.
v. [lamented; lamented; lamenting] to mourn or grieve E.G. The boy is lamenting the loss of his pet. Pedro's only lament was that his wife didn't outlive him.

adj. lacking vitality; indifferent E.G. The languid student was always late to class. I have studied so much that I have grown languid to the subject. During her illness she was so languid she could not leave her bed.
n. [larcenies] theft; stealing E.G. After robbing the liquor store, she was found guilty of larceny.
adj. indecent; immoral E.G. He said it was a harmless pin-up poster, but his mother called it lascivious. Known as a skirt-chaser, his lascivious ways seemed to all but preclude a stable marriage.
n. a state of being tired or listless E.G. Lassitude was evident in the nurses who had been working for 24 hours straight. Ten days of continual work caused a feeling of lassitude for the worker.
n. [latencies] a period of inactivity E.G. Its latency was small solace for the girl who feared that the cancer would re-emerge fiercer than ever.
v. [lauded; lauded; lauding] praise E.G. He lauded his daughter for winning the trophy.
adj. [laxer; laxest] careless; irresponsible E.G. She was lax in everything she did and therefore could not be trusted with important tasks.

adj. impure in thought and act E.G. The lecherous Humbert Humbert is Nabokov's protagonist in Lolita, a novel that sparked great controversy because of Humbert's romantic attachment to a young girl. The lecherous man lurked on the corner.
adj. lazy; passive E.G. Feeling very lethargic, he watched television or slept the whole day.
n. [levees] a landing on the edge of a river or field E.G. The swimmer came ashore on the levee.

n. [levities] lack of seriousness; instability E.G. The levity with which he faced the destruction hampered the rescue effort. Levity characterized the first months of his administration. Levity is a necessary trait for a comedian.
adj. [lewder; lewdest] lustful; wicked E.G. The comment was so lewd it could not be repeated in front of children.
n. connection; link E.G. The student council served as a liaison between the faculty and the student body.
n. believing in personal freedom (favoring reform or progress) E.G. If you believe in liberalism, the First Amendment is sacrosanct.
n. one who indulges his desires without restraint E.G. For the libertine, missing his child's birthday was not as significant as missing a football game.
adj. morally lacking in restraint E.G. The people of Sodom and Gomorra were known for their licentious lifestyle.
adj. having the composition of wood E.G. The ligneous material appeared to be pure maple.
adj. flexible; pliant E.G. The dancers must be limber to do their ballet steps.
adj. [lither; lithest] easily bent; pliable E.G. It is best to use a lithe material when constructing a curved object. A gymnast needs to be lithe in order to do a split.
v. [litigated; litigated; litigating] to involve a lawsuit E.G. A number of the state attorneys-general are litigating against the tobacco companies.
adj. discolored, as if bruised; extremely angry E.G. After the fall, her arm was livid. She became livid when she heard the news. When she found out she had been robbed, the woman was livid.
v. [loitered; loitered; loitering] to spend time aimlessly E.G. Many teenagers loiter around the mall when there is nothing else to do.

adj. very talkative; garrulous E.G. She was having difficulty ending the conversation with her loquacious neighbor. The staff knew the meeting would be long because the administrator was in a loquacious mood.
adj. shining; translucent E.G. The flowing garment gave the woman a lucent quality when standing in the spotlight.
adj. shiny; clear minded E.G. He chose a shimmering, lucid fabric for his curtains. When lucid, the man spoke of vivid memories.
adj. profitable; gainful E.G. She entered the pharmaceutical industry in the belief that it would be lucrative.
adj. full of sorrow; mournful E.G. The man's lugubrious heart kept him from enjoying the special occasion.

adj. emitting light; shining E.G. The luminous quality of the precious stone made it look like a fallen star. They found their way through the darkness by heading toward the luminous object in the distance.
v. [lunged; lunged; lunging] to move suddenly E.G. The owl will lunge at its prey in order to take it off guard.
adj. glowing through haze; shocking, sensational E.G. A lurid sun shone upon them as they watched the sun set on the beach. The tabloid specialized in lurid stories about celebrities' indiscretions.
adj. bright; radiant E.G. Surrounded by rubies, the lustrous diamond looked magnificent.
adj. to grow with energy and in great abundance E.G. The luxuriant flowers grew in every available space.

v. [macerated; macerated; macerating] to soften by steeping in liquid E.G. It was necessary to macerate the food before the elderly man could eat it. They placed her foot in the solvent to macerate the cement she had stepped in.
adj. spotted, blotched; hence defiled, impure (opposite: immaculate) E.G. The maculate rug could not be cleaned. Grape juice maculated the carpet.

n. [magnanimities] a quality of nobleness of mind, disdain of meanness or revenge E.G. Being full of magnanimity he asked the thief only for an apology and set him free. The magnanimous store owner did not press charges once an apology was given. The magnanimity of the professor overcame the rage of the student.

n. putting a curse on someone; talking negatively about another E.G. With the threat of a malediction, the man left the fortuneteller's house. Never having a nice word to say about anyone, her conversations are full of malediction.
n. an evil person E.G. The malefactor ordered everyone to work over the holidays. The prison contains malefactors of all ages.
adj. wishing evil (opposite: benevolent) E.G. The man threatened his opponent with threats and malevolent words. She had malevolent feelings toward her sister.
adj. spiteful; vindictive E.G. The malicious employee slashed her tires for revenge.

v. [maligned; maligned; maligning] to speak evil of E.G. In her statement to the judge she maligned her soon-to-be ex-husband. She had such a malign personality that no one even tried to approach her, mostly out of fear.
v. [malingered; malingered; malingering] to pretend to be ill in order to escape work E.G. He will malinger on Friday so he can go to the movies. The soldier will malinger to avoid fighting.
adj. easy to shape or bend; pliable E.G. The malleable material was formed into a U shape. The sculptor uses malleable substances to create complex masterpieces.
n. [mandates] order; charge E.G. The new manager wrote a mandate declaring that smoking was now prohibited in the office.

v. [manifested; manifested; manifesting] to show clearly; to appear E.G. The image should manifest itself as the building when the fog lifts. When the missing document suddenly manifested, the search for the person that buried it began. America's manifest destiny was to acquire all of the land between the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans.
v. [marred; marred; marring] damage E.G. The statue was marred by the ravages of time.
n. [marauders] plunderer or raider E.G. The marauder had been traveling for two months searching for the large stash.

n. the belief that everything in the universe is explained in terms of matter; the belief that worldly possessions are the be-all and end-all in life E.G. Spiritualists will tell you that materialism is only half the story. Some said that the prince's profligacy gave materialism a bad name.
adj. foolishly and tearfully sentimental E.G. The maudlin affair consisted of three speeches in honor of the benefactor.
n. a person who does not conform to the norm E.G. The maverick drove a large truck as others were purchasing compact cars.

v. [meandered; meandered; meandering] wind, wander E.G. The stream meanders through the valley. Because we took a long, meandering walk, we arrived home well after dark. They meandered through the woods for the afternoon.
n. depression; gloom E.G. The funeral parlor was filled with the melancholy of mourning.
adj. having a sweet sound E.G. The flute had a beautifully mellifluous sound.
adj. pleasing to hear E.G. The melodious sounds of the band attracted many onlookers.
n. [menageries] a place to keep or a collection of wild or strange animals E.G. Little Ryan couldn't wait to visit the zoo to see the menagerie of wild boars.
adj. not truthful; lying E.G. The couple was swindled out of their life's savings by the mendacious con men.
n. teacher; wise and faithful advisor E.G. Alan consulted his mentor when he needed critical advice.

n. [mercenaries] one that serves merely for wages E.G. A mercenary was hired for a hundred dollars a month, good money in those days even if you had to fight a war to get it. Lila was suspicious that Joe had jumped at the chance only for mercenary reasons.
adj. quick, changeable, fickle E.G. The mercurial youth changed outfits six times before deciding what to wear.
adj. deceptive beauty - alluring by attractive appearance E.G. A cubic zirconia is a meretricious way of impressing others.
v. [mesmerized; mesmerized; mesmerizing] hypnotize E.G. The swaying motion of the swing mesmerized the baby into a deep sleep.
n. [metamorphoses] change of form E.G. A metamorphosis caused the caterpillar to become a beautiful butterfly.
adj. exacting; precise E.G. The lab technicians must be meticulous in their measurements to obtain exact results.
n. spirit, courage, ardor E.G. He proved he had the mettle to make it through basic training.
n. appearance, being or manner E.G. Her mien was typically one of distress, especially after the mishap.
n. imitation E.G. The comedian's mimicry of the president's gestures had the audience rolling in the aisles.
adj. threatening E.G. The minatory stance of the dog warned the thief of an attack.
adj. extremely small, tiny E.G. Being on a sodium-restricted diet, he uses only a minute amount of salt in his dishes.
v. [mired; mired; miring] to cause to get stuck in wet, soggy ground E.G. The car became mired in the mud.
n. a person who distrusts everything; a hater of mankind E.G. After the man swindled all of the woman's savings, she became a misanthrope. The misanthrope lived alone in the forest.
adj. evil E.G. Her miscreant actions shocked and surprised her family. The miscreant thought nothing of taking others' money and belongings.
n. [misers] penny pincher, stingy person E.G. The miser made no donations and loved counting his money every night.

n. [mites] a very small sum of money; very small creature E.G. The mite they pay me is hardly worth the aggravation. The baseball team was made up of such small children they were nicknamed the Mites.
v. [mitigated; mitigated; mitigating] alleviate; lessen E.G. She tried to mitigate the loss of his pet by buying him a kitten. The lawyer will attempt to mitigate the sentence probation.

v. [modulated; modulated; modulating] to regulate or adjust; to vary the pitch E.G. He modulated the color knob on the television set until the picture was perfect. A trained singer knows how to modulate her voice to the desired pitches.
v. [mollified; mollified; mollifying] to soften; to make less intense E.G. We used our hands to mollify the sound of our giggling.
adj. melted E.G. Steel becomes molten after heating it to thousands of degrees.
adj. subject to or open for discussion or debate E.G. The discussion of extending the girl's curfew was a moot point.
adj. cutting; sarcastic E.G. Her mordant remark made me feel unqualified and useless.
adj. moody, despondent E.G. He was very morose over the death of his pet. After the team lost the fans were morose.
n. [motifs] theme E.G. Although the college students lived in Alaska, they decided on a tropical motif for their dorm room. The decorations include a rose motif.
n. spontaneous motion E.G. The motility of the car caused the driver to lunge for the brake.
adj. ordinary; commonplace E.G. The small town was very mundane. Going food shopping soon became mundane, losing all of its excitement.
adj. giving generously E.G. The civic group made a munificent donation to the homeless shelter.
v. [mused; mused; musing] to think or speak meditatively E.G. I expect I'll have to muse on that question for a while.
n. [myriads] a large number E.G. Buying an old house often necessitates fixing a myriad of problems. Gazing up on the clear, dark midnight sky, the astronomer saw a myriad of stars.
adj. egotistical; self-centered E.G. The narcissistic actor was difficult to get along with.
adj. starting to grow or develop E.G. The nascent rage of in-line skating began on the West Coast.
adj. of the sea; having to do with sailors, ships, or navigation E.G. The coastal New England town had a charming nautical influence.
adj. unclear or vague E.G. The ten page directions were a collection of nebulous words and figures.
adj. morally bad; wicked E.G. The nefarious criminal was the scourge of the local police force.
adj. being villainous or wicked E.G. The nefariousness of the ruler was apparent when he hoarded all of the food.
n. carelessness E.G. Negligence contributed to the accident: She was traveling too fast for the icy conditions.
n. [nemeses] a person who inflicts just punishment; retribution E.G. The criminal was killed by his nemesis, the brother of the man he murdered. The football team plays its nemesis on Saturday.
n. giving a new meaning to an old word E.G. Bad is a neologism for good.

n. beginner; newcomer E.G. Critics applauded the neophyte's success and speculated how much better he would get with age and experience. The neophyte dancer was overcome by the fast tempo and exotic rhythms.
v. [nettled; nettled; nettling] annoy; irritate E.G. The younger brother nettled his older sister until she slapped him. The boy will nettle the father into agreeing.
adj. [more neutral; most neutral] impartial; unbiased E.G. The mother remained neutral regarding the argument between her two children.
n. [nexus] a connection E.G. The nexus between the shuttle and the space station was successful.
adj. harmful to health; having a foul odor E.G. The noisome food was the cause of their illness. The family was forced from the home by a noisome odor.
adj. longing for the past; filled with bittersweet memories E.G. She loved her new life, but became nostalgic when she met with her old friends.
n. a questionable remedy for difficulties E.G. The doctor's prescription was so unusual that it could be seen as a nostrum. The nostrum of pine leaves and water did not seem to cure the illness.

adj. [more notorious; most notorious] infamous; renowned E.G. Discovering that her new neighbor was notorious for thievery, she decided to purchase an alarm system for her home. The criminal had a notorious reputation.
adj. new E.G. It was a novel idea for the rock group to play classical music.
adj. [more noxious; most noxious] harmful to one's health E.G. The noxious fumes caused the person to become ill.
adj. trifling; futile E.G. Because the problem was nugatory it was not addressed immediately.
v. [nullified; nullified; nullifying] cancel; invalidate E.G. Drinking alcohol excessively will nullify the positive benefits of eating well and exercising daily.
n. a clumsy, dumb person E.G. The waiter has been called an oaf ever since he dropped the tray.
adj. stubborn E.G. The obdurate child refused to go to school. The obdurate youngster refused to eat the Brussels sprouts.
n. [obeisances] a gesture of respect or reverence E.G. As an obeisance, the man took off his hat as the funeral procession drove past him.
v. [obfuscated; obfuscated; obfuscating] to darken, confuse, bewilder E.G. The lunar eclipse will obfuscate the light of the sun.

adj. [more objective; most objective] open-minded; impartial E.G. It's hard to set aside your biases and be objective. The law student decided that her primary objective after graduation was to pass the Bar examination.
v. [objurgated; objurgated; objurgating] to chide vehemently E.G. The girls disliked those boys who objurgated the group.
adj. mandatory; necessary E.G. In order to provide a reliable source of revenue for the government, it is obligatory for each citizen to pay taxes.
v. [obliterated; obliterated; obliterating] destroy completely E.G. Poaching nearly obliterated the world's whale population.

n. [obloquies] widespread condemnation or abuse; disgrace or infamy resulting from this. E.G. The child suffered quite an obloquy at the hands of his classmates. Lawyers must face frequent obloquy with their reputation as ambulance chasers.
adj. [obscurer; obscurest] not easily understood; dark E.G. The orchestra enjoys performing obscure American works, hoping to bring them to a wider audience.

adj. [more obsequious; most obsequious] servilely attentive; fawning E.G. The man's attraction to the woman would be obvious if his obsequious behavior could be noted. The princess only seemed to encourage the obsequious behavior of her court to enhance her own feeling of superiority.
adj. out of date; pass' E.G. Computers have made many formerly manual tasks obsolete.
adj. [more obstinate; most obstinate] stubborn E.G. Her father would not allow her to stay out past midnight; she thought he was obstinate because he would not change his mind.
v. [obtruded; obtruded; obtruding] to force oneself or one's ideas upon another; to thrust forward E.G. The inquisitive coworker obtrudes into the conversation often.

adj. dull; greater than 90 but less than 180 E.G. The man was so obtuse, he even made the dog yawn. The textbook problem asks the reader to solve for the obtuse angle. He's obtuse when it comes to abstract art.

v. [obviated; obviated; obviating] to make unnecessary E.G. The invention of cars has obviated the use of horse and carriage. A cure for the common cold would obviate the need for shelf after shelf of cold remedies.

adj. hidden; beyond human understanding E.G. The occult meaning of the message was one of dislike for the authorities. Some spend years pursuing the occult, only to find themselves no closer to the answer. Relating to the occult world means entering a new realm.
adj. [more odious; most odious] hateful; disgusting E.G. Having to chaperone her brother was an odious chore for the girl.
n. a hate; the disgrace from a hateful action E.G. Odium could be felt for the man who destroyed the school.
n. [oligarchies] form of government in which the supreme power is placed in the hands of a small, exclusive group. E.G. The oligarchy took control after the king was overthrown.
adj. [more ominous; most ominous] threatening E.G. Seeing ominous clouds on the horizon, the street fair organizers decided to fold up their tent and go home.
adj. having knowledge of all things E.G. The future can be told by the omniscient woman.
adj. iridescent E.G. Her new nail polish was opalescent making her finger tips look like pearls.
adj. dull; cloudy E.G. Not having been washed for years, the once beautiful windows of the Victorian home became opaque. They chose an opaque shade of green for their bathroom walls.
adj. abusive E.G. Nobody liked working for him because he was so opprobrious.
n. person who hopes for the best; sees the good side E.G. He's ever the optimist, always seeing the glass as half full.
n. wealth; fortune E.G. A 40-room mansion on 65 wooded acres is only the most visible sign of her opulence.
adj. [more ornate; most ornate] elaborate; lavish E.G. The courthouse was framed by ornate friezes.

adj. [more orthodox; most orthodox] traditional; accepted E.G. The gifted child's parents concluded that orthodox methods of education would not do their son any good, so they decided to teach him at home.

v. [oscillated; oscillated; oscillating] to move back and forth; to have a wavering opinion E.G. The oscillating sprinkler system covered the entire lawn. The couple often oscillates between going out and staying home.
v. [ossified; ossified; ossifying] to turn to bone; to harden E.G. Over time, the plant matter has ossified. The tablet will ossify when left in the sun.
adj. apparent E.G. The ostensible reason for choosing the girl was for her beauty.
adj. [more ostentatious; most ostentatious] being showy E.G. Sure he'd won the lottery, but coming to work in a stretch limo seemed a bit ostentatious .
v. [ostracized; ostraized; ostracizing] to exclude E.G. The students tend to ostracize the children they dislike from their games.
v. [ousted; ousted; ousting] drive out; eject E.G. The dictator was ousted in a coup detat.
n. a song of praise or triumph E.G. A paean was written in honor of the victorious warrior.
adj. polytheistic E.G. Moses, distraught over some of his people's continuing pagan ways, smashed the stone tablets bearing the Ten Commandments.
adj. thorough, careful, precise E.G. Helga's painstaking research paid off with a top grade on her essay.
adj. large and ornate, like a palace E.G. The new palatial home contained two pools and an indoor track for jogging.
n. a word or phrase which reads the same backwards and forwards E.G. Bob, Dad, and Madam are examples of palindromes.

v. [palliated; palliated; palliating] to alleviate or ease pain but not cure; to make appear less serious E.G. The medication will help palliate the pain. The lawyer attempted to palliate the offense to the jury.
adj. [more pallid; most pallid] pale in color E.G. The visitor left the hospital room with a pallid face.
n. lack of facial color E.G. The more vivid the testimony grew, the more the witness seemed to take on a ghostly pallor.

adj. touchable; clear, obvious E.G. The palpable decision was to discontinue the use of drugs. On a flight that had included a sudden 5,000-foot drop, the passengers' relief upon landing was palpable .
n. high praise E.G. Upon his retirement, he received a great panegyric from many of his associates. His panegyric to his opponent stood in sharp contrast to the harsh tenor of the campaign.
n. model, prototype; pattern E.G. The machine could no longer be produced after the paradigm was destroyed. The Massachusetts gubernatorial race was considered a paradigm of campaign civility.

n. [paradoxes] a tenet seemingly contradictory or false, but actually true E.G. The paradox seemed so unlikely though it was true. At first blush, the company's results were a paradox: Sales were down, yet profits were up.
n. [parapets] a wall for protection; a low wall or railing E.G. The parapet protected the kingdom from the raging army. The parapet kept the child from falling into the river.
n. equipment; accessories E.G. She looked guilty since the drug paraphernalia was found in her apartment.
n. an outcast E.G. The pariah of the group sat by himself under the tree.
n. [parities] state of being the same in power, value, or rank E.G. When the younger brother was promoted to co-president with the elder son, it established parity between the two.
v. [parleyed; parleyed; parleying] to speak with another; to discourse E.G. I will parley the information to the appropriate person.

adj. religious; narrow-minded E.G. Devout Christians, the Chesterfields enrolled their children in a parochial school. Governor Kean urged Republicans to rise above parochial interests and be the party of inclusion.

n. [parodies] a piece of work imitating another in a satirical manner; a poor imitation E.G. The play was a parody of the Prince and Princess's marital difficulties. Ugh! This is a parody of a fashionable dress!
v. [parried; parried; parrying] to avoid; to ward off E.G. I dislike talking to the woman so I will attempt to parry her by ducking around the corner.
v. [parsed; parsed; parsing] to separate (a sentence) into parts and describe the function of each E.G. An English teacher may ask a student to parse a sentence.

adj. very frugal; unwilling to spend E.G. The owner was so parsimonious he refused to purchase new curtains when the old ones fell off the window. The parsimonious individual argued that twenty-five cents was much too expensive for a pack of gum.
n. to be unreasonably careful when spending E.G. The parsimony of the wealthy woman was uncalled for.
n. [partisans] supporter; follower E.G. The union president is a partisan of minimum-wage legislation. A partisan for the incumbent mayor will not support the challenger.
adj. [more passive; most passive] submissive; unassertive E.G. He is so passive that others walk all over him.
n. scarcity E.G. The described feast was actually a buffet with a paucity of food.
n. [pavilions] a large tent or covered area, usually used for entertainment E.G. The wedding pavilion was not only beautifully decorated, but also served as welcome protection from a sudden downpour.
n. [peccadilloes, peccadillos] a slight fault or offense E.G. The child was embarrassed when he was caught committing the peccadillo of eating chocolate before dinner.
adj. pertaining to money E.G. The retiring employee was delighted when he received a pecuniary gift.
n. a teacher E.G. Seeing the way she worked with children there was no doubt she was a true pedagogue.

adj. [more pedantic; most pedantic] emphasizing minutiae or form in scholarship or teaching E.G. Professor Jones's lectures were so pedantic that his students sometimes had a tough time understanding the big picture. It is important to understand pedantic terminology before beginning a lecture.
adj. mediocre; ordinary E.G. We expected the meal to be exceptional, but it was just pedestrian.
adj. making things worse E.G. The pejorative comment deepened the dislike between the two families.
adj. transparent E.G. The pellucid material was not an adequate shield from the sun.
n. a liking for E.G. I have a penchant for all flavors of ice cream.
adj. feeling sorry for what one has done E.G. The burglar expressed his penitent feelings during his confession.

adj. [more pensive; most pensive] reflective; contemplative E.G. She was in a pensive mood, just wanting to be alone to think. My hours alone are often more pensive than the time I spend with friends. The pensive mood was broken by a witty joke.
adj. stingy, miserly E.G. The penurious man had millions of dollars, but lived in a cottage to save money. Charles Dickens' Scrooge is the most penurious character in any of his tales.
adj. full of insight; aware E.G. The perceptive detective discovered that the murder weapon was hidden in a safe under the floor.
n. striking one object against another E.G. The loud percussion of the hunter's gunshot startled the birds.
n. ruination E.G. The perdition of the building was caused by the strong quake.

adj. [more peremptory; most peremptory] barring future action; that cannot be denied, changed, etc. E.G. The peremptory means of defense was satisfactory to keep out the intruders. The wildcat strike was a peremptory move on the part of the workers.
adj. faithless; treacherous E.G. The trust between the business associates was broken after the perfidious actions by one of the partners.

adj. [more perfunctory; most perfunctory] done in a routine, mechanical way, without interest E.G. Change in career is a good cure for someone who has become bored with their occupation and is currently performing their duties in a perfunctory fashion. The girl will not improve unless she changes her perfunctory attitude.

adj. marginal; outer E.G. Those are peripheral problems; let's look at the central challenge. The peripheral shrubs were used to create a fence-like blockade. He thought he was my best friend, when in fact, he was a peripheral acquaintance.

n. [perjuries] the practice of lying E.G. The already sensational trial of a star athlete turned all the more so when it turned out that a police detective had committed perjury. Lying while on the witness stand is perjury.
adj. porous; allowing to pass through E.G. Because the material was permeable, the water was able to drain.

adj. [more pernicious; most pernicious] dangerous; harmful E.G. Standing oil combined with a fresh rain on the asphalt can have a pernicious impact on a driver's control of the road. The pernicious fire engulfed four blocks of homes.
adj. never ceasing; continuous E.G. Perpetual pain keeps the woman from walking.
n. extra payment; a tip E.G. After working overtime, I had enough money to make a perquisite on my loan.
adj. related to the matter at hand E.G. During a trial everyone should concentrate on the same subject, stating only pertinent information.
v. [perused; perused; perusing] to read carefully; to study E.G. A vast majority of time was spent perusing the possible solution to the dilemma.
v. [pervaded; pervaded; pervading] to occupy the whole of E.G. Her perfume was so strong that it pervaded the whole room.
adj. spreading throughout E.G. The home was filled with the pervasive aroma of baking bread.
n. seeing only the gloomy side; hopelessness E.G. After endless years of drought, pessimism grew in the hearts of even the most dedicated farmer.
adj. [pettier; pettiest] unimportant; of subordinate standing E.G. With all of the crime in the world, stealing bubble gum is considered petty theft.

adj. [more petulant; most petulant] peevish; cranky E.G. The long illness put the boy in a petulant mood. The tone of his voice and the things that he says become quite petulant when he has not gotten enough sleep.

n. [phenomena, phenomenons] exceptional person; unusual occurrence E.G. Not for nothing do they call Yankee Stadium The House that Ruth Built-the Babe was a phenomenon. The northern lights are a rare phenomenon for those not living near the Arctic Circle.
n. [philanthropies] charity; unselfishness E.G. After years of donating time and money to the children's hospital, Mrs. Elderwood was commended for her philanthropy.

adj. without emotion or interest; sluggish and dull E.G. The playwright had hoped his story would take theatergoers on an emotional roller coaster, but on opening night they just sat there, stonefaced and phlegmatic. The phlegmatic child rarely went outside to play.
n. [phobias] morbid fear E.G. Fear of heights is a not uncommon phobia.
adj. colored, blotched together E.G. The extreme heat caused the colors to become pied.
adj. bound fast E.G. The two rafts were pinioned by steel wire.

adj. religious; devout E.G. The religious couple believed that their pious method of worship would bring them eternal life. The statues of the saints have pious symbolism. Many people think of this land as pious territory.
n. resentment at being slighted E.G. Being passed over for the promotion aroused his pique. The more he piqued her, the redder she grew.
adj. [pithier; pithiest] terse and full of meaning E.G. Columnist William Safire, a former presidential speech writer, has a way with words that often yields pithy comments.
n. a small amount E.G. The reward money was only a pittance compared to the money lost. The little girl received a pittance every week for keeping her room clean.

v. [placated; placated; placating] to appease or pacify E.G. The entire family attempted to placate the stubborn child. With a soothing voice and the promise of a juicy steak, the trainer placated the escaped lion so that he wouldn't hurt anyone.
adj. [more placid; most placid] undisturbed and calm E.G. The placid lake's water was completely motionless.
adj. [more plaintive; most plaintive] being mournful or sad E.G. His wife's death made Sam plaintive.

adj. idealistic or impractical; not amorous or sensual E.G. The platonic advice of the doctor was to stay away from all odors. Our relationship is platonic now, but I hope it will someday be otherwise.

adj. [more plausible; most plausible] probable; feasible E.G. After weeks of trying to determine what or who was raiding the chicken coop, the farmer came up with a plausible explanation. After scrimping and saving for a decade, it was now plausible to send his daughter to college.
adj. full; entire E.G. A plenary class of students staged the protest.
n. a superabundance E.G. There was a plethora of food at the royal feast.
adj. perfectly straight down E.G. The two walls met plumb at the corner. I was able to plumb the riddle in a few seconds.
adj. controversial E.G. The polemic decision caused a stir in the community.
n. a person skilled in argument E.G. The polemicist could debate any case skillfully.
n. the rounded, upward-projecting front of a saddle E.G. The woman was so nervous about being on the horse she would not let go of the pommel.

adj. [more ponderous; most ponderous] unwieldy from weight; dull or labored E.G. The ponderous piano posed a serious challenge to having it pulled up to the 16th floor. As if being grainy wasn't bad enough, the film's ponderous story made it tough to get through.
v. [portended; portended; portending] to be an omen of; signify E.G. The distant roll of thunder portends of an oncoming storm.
adj. drinkable E.G. The liquid was not potable, but rather poisonous. Sea water isn't potable.
adj. [more potent; most potent] having great power or physical strength E.G. He took very potent medication and felt better immediately.

adj. matter-of-fact; practical E.G. Since they were saving money to buy a new home, the pragmatic married couple decided not to go on an expensive vacation. A pragmatic solution to the car's continual repairs would be to purchase a new car.
v. [prated; prated; prating] talking foolishly; chatter E.G. It is not uncommon for people to prate when they become nervous about speaking to a superior.
n. childish babble E.G. I've listened to his prattle for far too long. The toddler does more prattling than talking.

adj. [more precarious; most precarious] depending upon another; risky, uncertain E.G. The precarious plans fell through when the second couple changed their plans. My position in the negotiations was precarious at best.
n. [precepts] a rule or direction of moral conduct E.G. The organization believed their members should abide by certain precepts.
v. [precipitated; precipitated; precipitating] to cause to happen E.G. A rude comment may precipitate an argument. The precipitating flood caught the village off-guard.

v. [precluded; precluded; precluding] inhibit; make impossible E.G. A healthy diet and lifestyle will not preclude you from getting ill, although it improves your immune system. Exercise may help to preclude heart disease.
adj. [more precocious; most precocious] developed or matured earlier than usual E.G. The precocious eight year-old wanted to read the romance novel.

n. [predecessors] one who has occupied an office before another E.G. Although her predecessor did not accomplish any goals that would help the poor, the new mayor was confident that she could finally help those in need.
adj. coming before E.G. The prefatory comments informed the audience of what was to come.
n. [premises] the basis for an argument E.G. The prosecutor claimed that the defense lawyer's premise was shaky, and thus his whole argument was suspect.
adj. to outweigh; to be superior in amount, weight, etc. E.G. His positive qualities are the preponderate ones over his occasional rudeness.

n. [presages] an omen; a foreshadowing characteristic E.G. They considered the rainbow at their wedding a presage for a happy life. Bright sun in the morning was a good presage that it was going to be a good day.
n. knowing about something before it happens E.G. The morning of the big game I had a prescience that we would win.
adj. done by custom; unbending E.G. At the heart of the Australian aborigines' prescriptive coming-of-age rite for men is a walkabout.
adj. generally occurring E.G. Rain is usually more prevalent than snow during April.

v. [prevaricated; prevaricated; prevaricating] to speak equivocally or evasively, i.e., to lie E.G. The mayor's desperate attempt to prevaricate about the scandal was transparent to the voters. His mother knew no one else could have done it, but the child foolishly prevaricated about the stain on the rug.
adj. primitive, pure, uncorrupted E.G. The pristine lake had not been marred by pollution. She had such a pristine look about her, you would have thought she was an angel.
adj. private; confidential E.G. He was one of a handful of people privy to the news of the pending merger. Only the woman's best friend was privy to her secret.
n. honesty E.G. The young man's probity was reassuring to the fearful parent.
adj. being hard to deal with; unsolved situation E.G. The constant squeak of the door was problematic. The tense political struggle remains problematic.

adj. wasteful; lavish E.G. The actor's prodigal lifestyle ultimately led to his undoing. Spending his rent money on your birthday present was more than generous, it was prodigal. The prodigal gift by the poor woman was truly a thoughtful gesture.

adj. [more prodigious; most prodigious] wonderful; enormous E.G. The prodigious festivities lasted until the wee hours of the morning. The Empire State Building required a prodigious amount of steel to erect.
adj. [profounder; profoundest] deep; knowledgeable E.G. It was with profound regret and sorrow that the family had to leave their homeland for a more prosperous country.

n. great wastefulness; a large abundance of E.G. The profusion of the food-fight was unforgivable considering the worldwide hunger problem. The profusion of uneaten food was sent to the shelter. The wet winter brought about a profusion of mosquitoes.
n. children; offspring E.G. It is through his progeny that his name shall live on. The princes were the progeny of royalty.

n. [programs] the parts of entertainment; a plan for dealing with a matter E.G. The free-form music program on Sunday nights is virtually unique in commercial radio. The program for better health is to eat more vegetables and fruits. The store's computer program allows sale information to prompt at the register for certain items at certain hours.
v. [proliferated; proliferated; proliferating] to reproduce quickly E.G. Gerbils are known to proliferate quickly.
adj. fruitful E.G. The merger resulted in a prolific business which became an asset to the community.
n. [promontories] a piece of land jutting into a body of water E.G. The boat hit the rocky promontory, splitting the bow.
v. [propagated; propagated; propagating] to reproduce or multiply E.G. Rabbits and gerbils are said to propagate quickly.
n. [propensities] a natural tendency towards; bias E.G. I have a propensity to talk too fast. She has a propensity to hire men over women.
n. closeness in time or place; closeness of relationship E.G. The propinquity of the disasters put the community in chaos. The propinquity of the two stories was the basis of the teacher's lesson.
v. [propitiated; propitiated; propitiating] to win the goodwill of E.G. If I try my best I will hopefully propitiate my new supervisor.

adj. [more prosaic; most prosaic] tiresome; ordinary E.G. He wanted to do something new; he was tired of the prosaic activities his parents suggested each day. The only entertainment would be a prosaic game of cards.
v. [proselytized; proselytized; proselytizing] to convert from one belief or religion to another E.G. The preacher often attempts to proselytize wayward travelers.
n. an original draft or record of a document E.G. The protocol was given to the president once it was completed.
adj. well-known because it is commonly referred to E.G. King Solomon's proverbial wisdom has been admired through the ages.
adj. prudent; economical E.G. It was provident, in his opinion, to wait and buy the new car when he was financially secure.

adj. [more provincial; most provincial] regional; unsophisticated E.G. After living in the city for five years, he found that his family back home on the farm was too provincial for his cultured ways.
n. [provisos, provisoes] A clause stating a condition or stipulation E.G. The governor began the conference with a proviso stating the disastrous results of the flood.

adj. tempting; irritating E.G. In the movie Roger Rabbit, the animated Jessica Rabbit demurs when she's told she's provocative, saying that she's only drawn that way. The U.S. considered the invasion of Kuwait a provocative action.
v. [provoked; provoked; provoking] to stir action or feeling; arouse E.G. By calling him names, he was provoking a fight.
v. [quaffed; quaffed; quaffing] drinking deeply E.G. A dog will quaff if he becomes overheated.
n. marshy land E.G. The vehicle became stuck in the quagmire.
adj. [quainter; quaintest] old-fashioned; unusual E.G. One of the best qualities of the bed-and-breakfast was its quaint setting in the charming English village.
adj. [more qualified; most qualified] experienced, indefinite E.G. She was well qualified for the job after working the field for ten years.
n. [qualms] sudden feeling of uneasiness or doubt E.G. His qualms about flying disappeared once the plane landed softly.

n. [quandaries] dilemma E.G. Joe and Elizabeth were caught in a quandary: Should they spend Thanksgiving with his parents or hers? Unable to make a firm decision, I've been in this quandary for weeks. When the car broke down the commuter was left in a quandary.
n. isolation of a person or persons to prevent the spread of disease E.G. To be sure they didn't bring any contagions back to Earth, the astronauts were put under quarantine when they returned.
n. state of being at rest or without motion E.G. After a tough day on the shipping dock, one needs quiescence. A period of quiescence is useful to calm the nerves.
adj. inactive, at rest E.G. Everyone deserves a day off and should remain quiescent on Sundays. The Bible says that the Lord created the Earth in six days and on the seventh He was quiescent.
n. the pure essence of anything E.G. This story is the quintessence of American fiction.

n. peculiar behavior; startling twist E.G. Nobody's perfect - we all have our quirks. Our vacation went smoothly save for one quirk - a hurricane that came barreling into the coastline as we were preparing to head home. The plot of that movie had so many quirks that it became very hard to follow. Always needing to put the left shoe on first is a peculiar quirk.
adj. foolishly idealistic; romantically idealistic E.G. He was popular with the ladies due to his quixotic charm. She had a quixotic view of the world, believing that humans need never suffer.

adj. furious; with extreme anger E.G. The insult made him rabid. Discovering that the dog was rabid, the mail carrier knew he'd have to get a shot. He's been a rabid sports fan for as long as I have known him.
n. a person skilled at telling stories E.G. Our entertainment was a raconteur who told a story of talking animals.
n. the arrangement of branches; consequence E.G. One of the ramifications of driving fast is getting a speeding ticket.
adj. [more rampant; most rampant] growing unchecked; widespread E.G. Social unrest was rampant because of the lack of food available to the people.
n. [ramparts] a defense E.G. The ramparts where beginning to crumble.
adj. having a bad odor E.G. Left out too long, the meat turned rancid.
n. strong ill will; enmity E.G. Her rancor for the man was evident in her hateful expression. Sure they had their disagreements, but there was no rancor between them.
v. [ranted; ranted; ranting] to speak in a loud, pompous manner; rave E.G. He disputed the bill with the shipper, ranting that he was dealing with thieves.
adj. using force to take E.G. Rapacious actions were needed to take the gun from the intruder.

v. [ratified; ratified; ratifying] to make valid; confirm E.G. The Senate ratified the new law that would prohibit companies from discriminating according to race in their hiring practices. Hunters were called in to ratify the deer population.

v. [rationalized; rationalized; rationalizing] to offer reasons for; account for on rational grounds E.G. His daughter attempted to rationalize why she had dropped out of college, but she could not give any good reasons.
adj. disagreeable to the sense of hearing; harsh E.G. The raucous protesters stayed on the street corner all night, shouting their disdain for the whale killers.

v. [razed; razed; razing] to scrape or shave off; to obliterate or tear down completely E.G. The plow will raze the ice from the road surface. It must be time to give the cat a manicure; she razed my skin last night. They will raze the old Las Vegas hotel to make room for a $2.5 billion gambling palace.
n. [realms] an area; sphere of activity E.G. In the realm of health care, the issue of who pays and how is never far from the surface. The bounding islands were added to the realm of the kingdom.
n. [rebuffs] a blunt refusal to offered help E.G. The rebuff of her aid plan came as a shock.
n. refutation E.G. The lawyer's rebuttal to the judge's sentencing was to present more evidence to the case.

adj. stubbornly rebellious E.G. The boy became recalcitrant when the curfew was enforced. The recalcitrant youth dyed her hair purple, dropped out of school, and generally worked hard at doing whatever others did not want her to do.
n. [recessions] withdrawal; economic downturn E.G. Oscar's gum recession left him with sensitive teeth. Soaring unemployment in the nation's industrial belt triggered recession.
n. habitual or chronic relapse of criminal or antisocial offenses E.G. Even after intense therapy the parolee experienced several episodes of recidivism, and was eventually sent back to prison.

adj. mutual; having the same relationship to each other E.G. Hernando's membership in the Picture of Health Fitness Center gives him reciprocal privileges at 245 health clubs around the U.S. Although his first child was adopted, she had a reciprocal relationship with her father.
adj. solitary E.G. His recluse life seems to make him happy. Howard Hughes, among the most famous and enigmatic figures of the 20th century, ultimately retreated to a life as a recluse.
adj. hard to understand; concealed E.G. The students were dumbfounded by the recondite topic. Many scientific theories are recondite, and therefore not known at all by the general public.
v. [rectified; rectified; rectifying] correct E.G. The service manager rectified the shipping mistake by refunding the customer's money.
adj. resting E.G. The recumbent puppy stirred.
adj. disobedient of authority E.G. Recusant inmates may be denied privileges.
adj. sweet-smelling; having the odor of a particular thing E.G. The redolent aroma of the pie tempted everyone. The restaurant was redolent with the smell of spices.

adj. [more redundant; most redundant] wordy; repetitive E.G. The redundant lecture of the professor repeated the lesson in the text. Her comments were both redundant and sarcastic. With millions of transactions at stake, the bank built a redundant processing center on a separate power grid.
v. [refurbished; refurbished; refurbishing] to make new; renovate E.G. The Newsomes are refurbishing their old colonial home with the help of an interior designer.
v. [refuted; refuted; refuting] challenge; disprove E.G. He refuted the proposal, deeming it unfair.
adj. royal; grand E.G. The regal home was lavishly decorated and furnished with European antiques. The well-bred woman behaves in a regal manner.

v. [reiterated; reiterated; reiterating] to repeat again E.G. Rose found that she had to reiterate almost everything, leading her to fear her husband was going deaf. If you did not hear me the first time, I will reiterate the directions for you.

v. [relegated; relegated; relegating] banish; put to a lower position E.G. With Internal Affairs launching an investigation into charges that officer, Wicker had harassed a suspect, he was relegated to desk duty.
adj. [more relevant; most relevant] of concern; significant E.G. Asking applicants about their general health is relevant since much of the job requires physical strength.
v. [relinquished; relinquished; relinquishing] to let go; abandon E.G. House Speaker Jim Wright had to relinquish his position after an ethics investigation undermined his authority.
v. [remonstrated; remonstrated; remonstrating] to protest or object to E.G. The population will remonstrate against the new taxes.
