n. guilt; sorrow E.G. The prosecutor argued that the defendant had shown no remorse for his actions.
n. a new life; rebirth E.G. The renascence of the band resulted in a new recording contract.

v. [rent; rent; rending] to rip or pull from; to split with violence E.G. The kidnapper rent the newborn baby from the arms of its mother as she was leaving the hospital. A freakish water spout rent the fishing boat in half. Every morning, the 5:47 local out of New Brunswick rends the dawn's silence with its air horn.
v. [rendered; rendered; rendering] deliver; provide E.G. The Yorkville First Aid Squad was first on the scene to render assistance.
n. a person who abandons something, as a religion, cause or movement; a traitor E.G. Benedict Arnold remains one of the most notorious renegades in American history.
n. [repasts] food that is eaten E.G. The repast consisted of cheese, wine, and bread.
adj. [more replete; most replete] well supplied E.G. The kitchen came replete with food and utensils.
n. [replicas] copy; representation E.G. The equine sculpture was a replica of a Remington.
v. [reprehended; reprehended; reprehending] to reprimand; to find fault with E.G. Finding the need to reprehend the student's actions, she gave her detention.
v. [reproached; reproached; reproaching] to blame and thus make feel ashamed; to rebuke E.G. The major reproached his troops for not following orders.
v. [reprobated; reprobated; reprobating] to condemn; to reject E.G. The teacher will reprobate the actions of the delinquent student. His assertions were reprobated as inappropriate.
n. [reproofs] a rebuke E.G. For all his hard work, all he got was a reproof of his efforts.

v. [repudiated; repudiated; repudiating] to disown; to deny support for E.G. The man will repudiate all claims that he was involved in the deal. Although his party supported the bill, this senator repudiated it. The offer was repudiated because of its cost.
adj. inconsistent; resistance E.G. The repugnant actions of the man made others lose trust in him. Despite their efforts to convince her, she remained repugnant.
n. [resignations] quitting; submission E.G. He submitted his resignation because he found a new job. You could see the resignation on his face: Things just weren't working out as he'd expected.
adj. flexible; capable of withstanding stress E.G. The elderly man attributed his resilient health to a good diet and frequent exercise.
n. [resolutions] proposal; promise E.G. Former U.S. Senator George Mitchell journeyed to Ireland to help bring about a peaceful resolution to years of strife.
adj. resounding; re-echoing E.G. Beautiful resonant music escaped from the cathedral's windows.
n. recess; rest period E.G. The workers talked and drank coffee during the respite. The team was given a respite from the long practice schedule.
adj. dazzling and shining E.G. Her new diamond was resplendent in the sunshine.
adj. rising or tending to rise again E.G. A resurgent wave of enthusiasm erupted from the once quiet crowd.
adj. silent; reserved E.G. The reticent girl played with her building blocks while the other children played tag. It was difficult to get the reticent boy to join the conversation.
v. [retracted; retracted; retracting] to draw or take back E.G. Once you say something, it's hard to retract.
n. a reverse action E.G. The retroaction of the car sent those standing behind it fleeing. The bill's retroaction stood to save taxpayers an average of $500 a head.
adj. [more reverent; most reverent] respectful; feeling or showing deep love, respect, or awe E.G. The congregation was very reverent of its spiritual leader.

n. the condition of being unaware of one's surroundings, trance; dreamy thinking or imagining, especially of agreeable things E.G. As their anniversary neared, Lisa fell into a reverie as she recalled all the good times she and Roscoe had had. After spending the morning in reverie, I decided to work in the afternoon.
v. [reviled; reviled; reviling] to be abusive in speech E.G. It is not appropriate for a teacher to revile a student.

v. [rhapsodized; rhapsodized; rhapsodizing] to speak or write in a very enthusiastic manner E.G. Hearing the general rhapsodize about his time as a plebe sent a wave of recognition through the academy grads.

adj. having to do with verbal communication; artificial eloquence E.G. In posing a rhetorical question, he hoped to get people thinking. The perception that Gary Hart was spouting rhetorical flourishes enabled fellow Democrat Walter Mondale to score debate points by asking, Where's the beef?
adj. vulgar joking or mocking E.G. Some people find the comedian's ribald act offensive. The ribald story proved an embarrassment to its audience.
n. [rigors] severity E.G. She criticized the planning board's vote with rigor.

v. [riveted, rivetted; riveted, rivetted; riveting, rivetting] to secure; to hold firmly, as in eyes E.G. We can rivet the boat to the dock. She could not look away from the morbid scene; she was riveted to it.
adj. rose-colored E.G. The roseate sunset faded into the sky.

n. [routs] a noisy or disorderly crowd; a retreat or terrible defeat E.G. The rout kept the police busy all morning with crowd control. The Scarlet Knights beat the Fighting Irish in a rout, 56-14. I need to rout the backyard in order to put in the pipes.
adj. [more rudimentary; most rudimentary] elementary E.G. Adding two plus two is a rudimentary activity.
n. [ruffians] tough person or a hoodlum E.G. Contrary to popular opinion, ruffians are nothing new in the city.
v. [ruminated; ruminated; ruminating] to consider carefully E.G. The doctor will ruminate on his diagnosis. Facing a tough decision, he decided to ruminate before making his thoughts known.
v. [rummaged; rummaged; rummaging] search thoroughly E.G. Determined to find his college yearbook, he rummaged through every box in the garage.
adj. [more rustic; most rustic] plain and unsophisticated; homely E.G. The president enjoyed spending weekends at Camp David, a rustic retreat in the Catoctin Mountains of Maryland.
n. [sagas] a legend; any long story of adventure or heroic deed E.G. The saga of King Arthur and his court has been told for generations.
adj. [more sagacious; most sagacious] wise E.G. Many of her friends came to her with their problems because she gave sagacious advice. The old man gave sagacious advice.

adj. [more salient; most salient] noticeable; prominent E.G. What's salient about the report is its documentation of utter despair in the heartland of the richest nation on Earth. His most salient feature is his nose. His salient bruise will alert his mother to the altercation.
adj. promoting good health E.G. Salubrious food helps maintain an ideal weight. Exercising frequently and eating healthy foods are salubrious habits.
adj. of or containing greetings E.G. Two messengers were sent to the new neighbors with a salutatory letter.
v. [salvaged; salvaged; salvaging] rescue from loss E.G. The family tried to salvage their belongings after their home was destroyed by a tornado.

v. [sanctioned; sanctioned; sanctioning] an act of giving authoritative permission; to give encouragement E.G. The government has sanctioned the meetings as a worthy cause. He did more than tolerate her actions, he sanctioned them. Before committing troops to war, the president wanted to give the sanctions a chance to work.

adj. [more sanguine; most sanguine] optimistic; cheerful E.G. Even when victory seemed impossible, the general remained sanguine. The dress was sanguine with a bright green border stripe. With a sanguine nod the interviewee entered the office.
adj. having a pleasant taste E.G. Yellow and blue icing covered the sapid pastry.
n. [sarcasms] ironic; bitter humor designed to wound E.G. The teacher did not appreciate the student's sarcasm and gave him detention.
adj. [more sardonic; most sardonic] having a sarcastic quality E.G. H.L. Mencken was known for his sardonic writings on political figures.
n. [satires] a novel or play that uses humor or irony to expose folly E.G. The new play was a satire that exposed the President's inability to lead the country.
v. [saturated; saturated; saturating] soak thoroughly; drench E.G. She saturated the sponge with soapy water before she began washing the car.
adj. gloomy, sluggish E.G. The never-ending rain put everyone in a saturnine mood.
v. [sauntered; sauntered; sauntering] to walk at a leisurely pace; stroll E.G. The loving couple sauntered down the wooded path.
n. [savants] one who is intelligent E.G. The savant accepted his award of excellence.
v. [savored; savored; savoring] to receive pleasure from; to enjoy with appreciation E.G. After several months without a day off, she savored every minute of her week-long vacation.
adj. [scantier; scantiest] inadequate; sparse E.G. The malnutrition was caused by the scanty amount of healthy food eaten each day.
n. a division in an organized group E.G. When the group could not decide on a plan of action, a schism occurred.
v. [scourged; scourged; scourging] to whip severely E.G. The trainer will scourge the animal if it attacks someone.

adj. honorable; exact E.G. After finding a purse with valuable items inside, the scrupulous Mr. Prendergast returned everything to its owner. A scrupulous cleaning was conducted before the family moved.
v. [scrutinized; scrutinized; scrutinizing] examine closely; study E.G. After allowing his son to borrow the family car, the father scrutinized every section for dents.
adj. vulgarity E.G. The scurrilous language made the mother twinge.
adj. to be narrow minded or limited E.G. A sectarian precluded him from listening to the other side.
adj. characterized by sitting; remaining in one locality E.G. The sedentary child had not moved after two hours. The old woman who never left her home town has led a sedentary life.
n. a revolt E.G. The sedition by the guards ended with their being executed for treason.
adj. working diligently; persistent E.G. The sedulous habits of the team will surely conclude in victory. Only the most sedulous salespeople will succeed.
v. [seethed; seethed; seething] to be violently disturbed E.G. By the time I arrived, she was seething with anger. He seethed at the prospect of losing the business to his conniving uncle.
v. [sequestered; sequestered; sequestering] to separate or segregate E.G. The jury was sequestered at the local inn.
n. an apparent aptitude for making fortunate discoveries accidentally E.G. Serendipity seemed to follow the lucky winner where ever he went.
adj. having a saw-toothed edge E.G. While camping, the family used a serrated band saw to cut firewood.

adj. slavish; groveling E.G. He knew they both possessed equal abilities, and yet he was always treated as a servile underling. His servile leadership forced her to take over. The servile nurse did everything the doctor told her to do.
adj. [shadier; shadiest] a character of questionable honesty E.G. A shady person would not be trusted with a sensitive secret.
n. [shoals] a large group or crowd E.G. Shoals of grain were stored in the barn.

adj. [shoddier; shoddiest] of inferior quality; cheap E.G. The state's attorney said many homes, as they were built with shoddy materials, were bound to just blow apart even in winds of 60 or 70 miles per hour. The shoddy homes were blown over in the storm.
adj. full of curves; twisting and turning E.G. Sinuous mountain roads at night present extra danger at night when it's harder to see the road's edge.
n. doubter E.G. Even after seeing evidence that his competitor's new engine worked, the engineer remained a skeptic that it was marketable.

v. [skulked; skulked; skulking] to move secretly, implies sinister E.G. The thief skulked around the neighborhood hoping to find his next target. They found the boy skulking in the bushes. The woman attempted to skulk away from cleaning the house by hiring a cleaning service.
v. [slandered; slandered; slandering] defame; maliciously misrepresent E.G. Orville said he'd been slandered, and he asked the court who would-or could- give him his name back.
n. [sloths] disinclination to action or labor E.G. Employers want to guard against hiring sloths as new employees.
adj. lazy E.G. The slothful actions of the player led to his benching.
adv. [slovenlier; slovenliest] sloppy E.G. His mother-in-law did not approve of his slovenly manner.
adj. soggy; dull in action as if from alcohol E.G. The flowers were sodden after the rain. The sodden reaction of the man caused the accident.
v. to stay temporarily E.G. The family will sojourn at their summer home. The guest remained only for a sojourn; she was going to leave in the afternoon.
n. [solaces] hope; comfort during a time of grief E.G. When her father passed away, she found solace amongst her friends and family.

n. [solemnities] a deep, reverent feeling often associated with religious occasions E.G. The church service was full of solemnity. The solemnity of the funeral procession stood in stark contrast to the young children splashing with delight in a nearby pool.
v. [solicited; solicited; soliciting] ask; seek E.G. The jobless man solicited employment from many factories before he was able to find work.

n. [soliloquies] a talk one has with oneself (esp. on stage) E.G. Imagine T.S. Eliot's poem The Waste Land performed on stage as a kind of soliloquy! The soliloquy by the man standing alone on the cliff sent a message of regret.
n. that can be solved; that can be dissolved E.G. The solubility of sugar causes it to disappear when put in water.
adj. dark and depressing; gloomy E.G. The sad story had put everyone in a somber mood.
adj. causing sleep E.G. The soporific medication should not be taken when you need to drive.
adj. filthy; base E.G. The sordid gutters needed to be cleaned after the long, rainy autumn. The criminals thought patterns were so sordid that he was not granted parole.
adj. superior E.G. The power was given to the sovereign warrior.

adj. plausible, but deceptive; apparently, but not actually, true E.G. The jury forewoman said the jury saw through the defense lawyer's specious argument and convicted his client on the weight of the evidence. I was unsure of the meaning of the specious statement.
n. one who studies caves E.G. The spelunker made a startling discovery in the old mine.
n. a person who spends money extravagantly E.G. The spendthrift bought two new necklaces and three pairs of shoes.
adj. marked by hostility E.G. The splenetic warriors advanced with no thought of what they were destroying.
adj. rarely occurring or appearing; intermittent E.G. In the desert there is usually only sporadic rainfall.
adj. not genuine, false; bogus E.G. Spurious claims by the importer hid the fact that prison labor had been used in the garments' fabrication. The newspaper was notorious for spurious information.

v. [spurned; spurned; spurning] to push away E.G. The woman spurned the advances of her suitor, saying she wasn't ready for a commitment. Unlucky enough to be the ninth telemarketer to call Jane that evening, he caught her spurn.
adj. filthy; wretched (from squalor) E.G. The lack of sanitation piping caused squalid conditions. He makes good money, but I would never want to work in those squalid crawl spaces.
adj. motionless, uncirculating E.G. The stagnant water in the puddle became infested with mosquitoes.
adj. [staider; staidest] marked by self-control E.G. The horse was staid as it entered the stable.
n. endurance E.G. Anybody who can finish the New York Marathon has lots of stamina.
v. [stanched; stanched; stanching] to stop or check the flow of; staunch E.G. It is necessary to stanch the bleeding from the wound as soon as possible.
n. [stanzas] group of lines in a poem having a definite pattern E.G. The poet uses an odd simile in the second stanza of the poem.
adj. inactive; changeless E.G. The view while riding in the train across the endless, flat landscape remained static for days. The static water of the lake reflected the image of the trees.
adj. [more steadfast; most steadfast] loyal E.G. The secret service agents are steadfast to their oath to protect the president.
n. [stigmata, stigmas] a mark of disgrace E.G. The F on his transcript is a stigma on his record.
v. [stigmatized; stigmatized; stigmatizing] to characterize or make as disgraceful E.G. The gross error will stigmatize the worker as careless.
n. payment for work done E.G. She receives a monthly stipend for her help with the project. The bank will pay the woman a stipend of a hundred dollars a week.
adj. detached; unruffled E.G. The soldier had been in week after week of fierce battle; nonetheless, he remained stoic. With stoic obedience the child sat quietly on the chair.
v. [stoked; stoked; stoking] to feed fuel to; especially a fire E.G. With the last embers dying, he stoked the fire one more time.
adj. showing little emotion E.G. With a stolid expression, the man walked away from the confrontation.
adj. having lines or grooves E.G. The striated road was ready for traffic.
n. harshness or shrillness sound E.G. The stridency of the whistle hurt the dog's ears.
adj. creaking; harsh, grating E.G. Her strident voice hampered her chances of getting the announcer position.
n. [stupors] a stunned or bewildered condition E.G. He was in a stupor after being hit on the head.
v. [stymied; stymied; stymieing] to hinder or obstruct E.G. Large amounts of snowfall will stymie the rescue effort.

adj. [suaver; suavest] effortlessly gracious E.G. She was a suave negotiator, always getting what she wanted without anyone feeling they'd lost anything. The elegant woman entered the room with a suave walk.

v. [subjugated; subjugated; subjugating] to dominate or enslave E.G. The bully will attempt to subjugate the remainder of the class. The royal family subjugated the peasants, making them perform hard labor.
adj. below the level of consciousness E.G. Critics of advertising say that it's loaded with subliminal messages.

adj. giving a service; being in a subordinate position E.G. The function of the subsidiary was to oversee the bank's commercial loans. He acknowledged the importance of the issue, but called it subsidiary to a host of other concerns.

adj. existing independently of others; a large quantity E.G. The only company not acquired in the merger retained its substantive existence. A substantive amount of money will be needed to fund the project.
v. [subsumed; subsumed; subsuming] to include within a larger group E.G. The AFL was subsumed by the NFL in the 1960s.

n. [subtleties] propensity of understatement; so slight as to be barely noticeable E.G. There was no subtlety in the protest; each person carried a sign and yelled for civil rights. With great subtlety we slipped away from the boring party.

adj. clearly stated; characterized by conciseness E.G. The speech was succinct yet emotional. Usually, the most succinct definition is the right one. Articles in USA Today are so succinct that some observers nicknamed the newspaper McPaper.
n. [succors] aid; assistance E.G. Succor was given to the fire victim in the form of clothes and temporary shelter.
v. [succumbed; succumbed; succumbing] give in; yield E.G. When dieting, it is difficult not to succumb to temptation.
v. [suffused; suffused; suffusing] to overspread E.G. The rain will suffuse the spilled sand around the patio.
adj. [more sumptuous; most sumptuous] involving great expense E.G. A sumptuous spread of meats, vegetables, soups and breads was prepared for the guests.
v. [sundered; sundered; sundering] break; split in two E.G. The Civil War threatened to sunder the United States. Management seeks to sunder the workers' connections to the union.
adj. various; miscellaneous E.G. This store sells many sundry novelty items. Sundry items may be purchased as a single item.
adj. [more superficial; most superficial] on the surface, narrow minded; lacking depth E.G. The victim had two stab wounds, but luckily were only superficial.

adj. unnecessary; extra E.G. Although the designer considered the piece superfluous, the woman wanted the extra chair in her bedroom. Only the first sentence is necessary; all of these details are superfluous. After they finished their seven-course meal, a large dessert seemed superfluous.
adj. of the highest kind or degree E.G. The Golden Gate Bridge is a superlative example of civil engineering.
v. [supplanted; supplanted; supplanting] to take the place of E.G. Can you supplant my position if I cannot play?
adj. asking earnestly and submissively E.G. Her suppliant request of wanting to know the name of the man was met with a laugh.
v. [suppressed; suppressed; suppressing] to bring to an end; hold back E.G. The illegal aliens were suppressed by the border patrol.
n. an overabundant supply; excessively indulging E.G. The result of her surfeit was a week of regret. The teenagers were warned not to surfeit at the party.
n. [surmises] a guess E.G. Was my surmise correct? I surmise that we will not. He surmised how the play would end before the second act began.
v. [surpassed; surpassed; surpassing] go beyond; out do E.G. After recovering from a serious illness, the boy surpassed the doctor's expectations by leaving the hospital two days early.
adj. done secretly E.G. The surreptitious maneuvers gave the advancing army an advantage.
adj. [more susceptible; most susceptible] easily imposed; inclined E.G. She gets an annual flu shot since she is susceptible to becoming ill.
v. [swathed; swathed; swathing] to wrap around something; envelop E.G. Soft blankets swathe the new born baby.
n. flatterer E.G. Rodolfo honed his skills as a sycophant, hoping it would get him into Sylvia's good graces. The sycophant is known for attending many parties.
n. reasoning in order from general to particular E.G. The syllogism went from fish to guppies.
n. [symmetries] correspondence of parts; harmony E.G. The roman columns give the building a symmetry.
adj. not real, rather artificial E.G. The synthetic skin was made of a thin rubber.
n. [tables] a systematic list of details E.G. The train schedule was set up as a table.
adj. not voiced or expressed E.G. The National Security Agency aide argued, in effect, that he had received the president's tacit approval for the arms-for-hostages deal.
adj. inclined to silence; speaking little E.G. The man was so taciturn it was forgotten that he was there.
v. [tantalized; tantalized; tantalizing] to tempt; to torment E.G. The desserts were tantalizing, but he was on a diet.
v. [tarried; tarried; tarrying] to go or move slowly; delay E.G. She tarried too long, and therefore missed her train.
adj. [tauter; tautest] stretched tightly E.G. They knew a fish was biting, because the line suddenly became taut.
adj. [tawdrier; tawdriest] tastelessly ornamented E.G. The shop was full of tawdry jewelry.
adj. [more tedious; most tedious] wearisome, tiresome E.G. Cleaning the house is a tedious chore for some people. With so many new safety precautions instituted, flying has become a tedious affair.
v. [teemed; teemed; teeming] to be stocked to overflowing; to pour out E.G. The new plant seemed to be teeming with insects. It is healthier to teem the grease from the broth before serving it.
n. [temerities] foolhardiness E.G. Temerity can result in tragedy if the activity is dangerous.

v. [tempered; tempered; tempering] to moderate, as by mingling with something else; to bring to the proper condition by treatment E.G. She drew a hot bath, but then realized she'd have to temper it with a little cool water or end up scalded. The craftsman tempered the steel before being able to twist it to form a table leg.
n. [temperaments] one's customary frame of mind E.G. The girl's temperament is usually very calm.

adj. [more tenacious; most tenacious] holding; persistent E.G. With a tenacious grip, the man was finally able to pull the nail from the wall. After his tenacious pleas, she finally conceded. His hold on his dreams is as tenacious as anyone I know.
n. a principle accepted as authoritative E.G. The tenets of socialism were explained in the book.
adj. undergoing or exerting tension E.G. The pipeline was capable of flexing to withstand the tremendous tensile strain that might accompany an seismic movement.
adj. not confirmed; indefinite E.G. Not knowing if he'd be able to get the days off, Al went ahead anyway and made tentative vacation plans with his pal.

adj. thin, slim, delicate; weak E.G. The hurricane force winds ripped the tenuous branches from the tree. The spectators panicked as they watched the cement block dangle from one tenuous piece of twine.
adj. lacking warmth, interest, enthusiasm; lukewarm E.G. The tepid bath water was perfect for relaxing after a long day.
n. a constantly quarrelsome woman E.G. Agreement with the termagant was an impossibility.
adj. pertaining to the earth E.G. Deer are terrestrial animals; fish are aquatic.
adj. [terser; tersest] concise; abrupt E.G. She believed in getting to the point, so she always gave terse answers. The terse speech contained only the essential comments.

n. [tethers] the range or limit of one's abilities; rope or chain used to keep a boat from drifting or an animal from wandering E.G. My tether of playing basketball is shooting air balls. The bulldog was tethered to his doghouse.
n. [thralls] a slave E.G. The worker was treated like a thrall, having to work many hours of overtime.
adj. [thriftier; thriftiest] frugal, careful with money E.G. Being thrifty, the woman would not purchase the item without a coupon. The thrifty couple saved money by taking the bus to work.
n. spasm or pang; agony E.G. A particularly violent throe knocked her off her feet. The wounded soldier squirmed in throes of agony.
v. [thwarted; thwarted; thwarting] prevent from accomplishing a purpose; frustrate E.G. Their attempt to take over the country was thwarted by the palace guard.
n. the quality of sound which distinguishes one from another E.G. The timbre of guitar music is different from that of piano music.
adj. lacking courage; timid E.G. The timorous child hid behind his parents. Hillary came to accept him as a timorous soul who needed succor.

adj. being dormant; slow, sluggish E.G. When we came upon the hibernating bear, it was in a torpid state. A torpid animal does not act with energy. The old, torpid dog spent most of his time sleeping.
adj. full of twists and turns; not straight forward E.G. The suspect confessed after becoming confused by the tortuous questioning of the captain.
adj. poisonous E.G. It's best to store cleansing solutions out of children's reach because of their toxic contents.
adj. easily managed (opposite: intractable) E.G. The boat was so lightweight it was tractable by one person. Having a tractable staff made her job a lot easier.
v. [traduced; traduced; traducing] to defame or slander E.G. His actions traduced his reputation.
n. peace; stillness E.G. The tranquillity of the tropical island was reflected in its calm blue waters and warm sunny climate.
n. a changed form E.G. Somewhere in the network's entertainment division, the show underwent a transmutation from a half-hour sitcom into an hour-long drama.
v. [transmuted; transmuted; transmuting] to transform E.G. Decorators transmute ordinary homes into interesting showcases.
v. [transpired; transpired; transpiring] to take place; come about E.G. With all that's transpired today, I'm exhausted.
adj. causing a violent injury E.G. It was a traumatic accident, leaving the driver with a broken vertebra, a smashed wrist, and a concussion.
n. [travails] very hard work; intense pain or agony E.G. The farmer was tired after the travail of plowing the fields. The analgesic finally ended her travail.
v. [trekked; trekked; trekking] to make a journey E.G. They had to trek through the dense forest to reach the nearest village.
adj. cutting; keen or incisive words E.G. Without a trenchant tool, they would have to break the branches rather than cut them. The trenchant words hurt the man deeply.
n. apprehension; uneasiness E.G. Her long absence caused more than a little trepidation. With great trepidation, the boy entered the water for the first time.
n. [tribunals] the seat of judge E.G. The tribunal heard the case of the burglary.
n. [tributes] expression of admiration E.G. Her performance was a tribute to her retiring teacher.
adj. [triter; tritest] commonplace; overused E.G. The committee was looking for something new, not the same trite ideas. Eating tomato salads became trite after their excessive popularity.
adj. [more trivial; most trivial] unimportant; small E.G. Although her mother felt otherwise, she considered her dish washing chore trivial.
n. belief; faith E.G. The couple pledged troth to each other through their vows.
adj. fierce, savage, cruel E.G. Truculent fighting broke out in the war-torn country. The truculent beast approached the crowd with wild eyes and sharpened claws.
v. [truncated; truncated; truncating] to shorten by cutting E.G. With the football game running over, the show scheduled to follow it had to be truncated.

adj. swollen; pompous E.G. The tumid river washed away the homes built on the shore. After he earned his high-school diploma, he became insufferably tumid. The tumid balloon floated, but the empty one did not.
n. [tumults] a noisy commotion; disturbance E.G. The tumult was caused by two boys wanting the same toy. After the tumult, I found it difficult to resume my studies.
adj. thick and dense; cloudy E.G. The turbid green waters of the lake prevented them from seeing the bottom.
n. condition of being physically agitated; disturbance E.G. Everyone on the plane had to fasten their seat belts as the plane entered an area of turbulence.
n. unrest; agitation E.G. Before the country recovered after the war, they experienced a time of great turmoil.
n. vileness E.G. The turpitude of the action caused a rage among the people.
n. the condition of being under a guardian or a tutor E.G. Being under the tutelage of a master musician is a great honor.
n. wealthy leader E.G. The business tycoon prepared to buy his fifteenth company.
n. [tyrannies] absolute power; autocracy E.G. The people were upset because they had no voice in the government that the king ran as a tyranny.
adj. omnipresent; present everywhere E.G. A ubiquitous spirit followed the man wherever he went. Water may seem ubiquitous, until a drought comes along.

adj. buried; concealed E.G. She was usually very selfish, so when she came bearing gifts he suspected that she had ulterior motives. My ulterior concerns are more important than my immediate ones. The man's ulterior motive was to spy on the lab, though he said he wanted a job.
n. offense or resentment E.G. The candidate took umbrage at the remark of his opponent.
adj. pure, of high quality E.G. An unalloyed chain is of greater value than a piece of costume jewelry.
adj. [uncannier; uncanniest] of a strange nature; weird E.G. That two people could be so alike was uncanny.
adj. uncultured; crude E.G. The social club would not accept an uncouth individual.

v. [undermined; undermined; undermining] to weaken; often through subtle means E.G. The attempts to undermine the merger were unsuccessful. The supervisor undermined the director's power and began controlling the staff.
adj. clear and unambiguous E.G. The 50-0 vote against the bill was an unequivocal statement against the measure. His response was unequivocal, which seemed unusual for a politician.
adj. genuine; real E.G. Her unfeigned reaction of surprise meant she had not expected the party.
adj. [ungainlier; ungainliest] clumsy and unattractive E.G. The ungainly man knocked over the plant stand.
adj. never changing, always with the same standard E.G. The marching band moved in uniform across the field. Patrons of fast-food chains say they like the idea of a uniform menu wherever they go.
adj. without equal; incomparable E.G. The jeweler assured him that the dubloon was unique, as it was part of the long lost treasure of the Atocha.
adj. concerning everyone; existing everywhere E.G. Pollution does not affect just one country or state- it's a universal problem.
adj. out of the way; remaining quietly in the background E.G. The shy man found an unobtrusive seat in the far corner of the room. It was easy to miss the unobtrusive plaque above the fireplace.
adj. unheard of; exceptional E.G. Weeks of intense heat created unprecedented power demands, which the utilities were hard pressed to meet.
adj. simple; plain E.G. He was an unpretentious farmer: An old John Deere and a beat-up Ford pick-up were all he needed to get the job done.
adj. [unrulier, more unruly; unruliest, most unruly] not submitting to discipline; disobedient E.G. The unruly boys had to be removed from the concert hall.
adj. improper; unfortunate E.G. Asking guests to bring their own food would be an untoward request. All of their friends expressed sympathy about their untoward separation.
adj. rare E.G. The unwonted raise would be the only one received for a few years. The changed migratory habits of the Canada geese, though unwonted, is unwanted because of the mess they make.
n. the final act or result E.G. The upshot of the debate was that the bill would be released to the floor.
adj. cultured; suave E.G. The gala concert and dinner dance was attended by the most urbane individuals. The English businessman was described by his peers as witty and urbane.
n. art of taking something for oneself; seizure E.G. During the war, the usurpation of the country forced an entirely new culture on the natives.

n. [usuries] the lending of money with an excessively high interest rate E.G. An interest rate 30 points above the prime rate would be considered usury in the United States. Loan sharks frequently practice usury, but their debtors usually have little choice but to keep quiet and pay up.
n. [utopias] imaginary land with perfect social and political systems E.G. Voltaire wrote of a utopia where the streets were paved with gold.
v. [wafted; wafted; wafting] move gently by wind or breeze E.G. The smoke wafted out of the chimney.

v. [waived; waived; waiving] to give up; to put off until later E.G. I will waive my rights to have a lawyer present because I don't think I need one. As hard as he tried, he could only waive his responsibility for so long.
adj. [wanner; wannest] lacking color; sickly pale E.G. Her face became wan at the sight of blood.

v. [waned; waned; waning] to gradually become less; to grow dim E.G. After time, interest in the show will wane and it will no longer be as popular. The full moon waned until it was nothing but a sliver in the sky.

adj. unmanageable; unjustifiably malicious E.G. My wanton hunger must be satiated. With wanton aggression, the army attacked the defenseless village. It is hard to lose weight when one has a wanton desire for sweets.
v. [warranted; warranted; warranting] justify; authorize E.G. The police official warranted the arrest of the suspect once enough proof had been found.

n. a confused mass; turmoil E.G. When the emergency alarm sounded, a welter of shivering office workers formed in the street as people evacuated the site. The welter moved from street to street to escape the fire.
v. [wheedled; wheedled; wheedling] to influence or persuade E.G. The crook may attempt to wheedle the money from the bank. He tried hard to wheedle his father into buying him a car.

v. [whetted; whetted; whetting] to sharpen by rubbing; to stimulate E.G. Before carving the turkey, you must whet the blade. The smell of cooking food has whet my appetite. The smell of dinner cooking whetted her appetite.
adj. fanciful; amusing E.G. Strolling down Disney World's Main Street is bound to put child and grown-up alike in a whimsical mood.
adj. [wilier; wiliest] concealing; sly E.G. The wily explanation was meant to confuse the investigator.
adj. charming; sweetly attractive E.G. His winsome words moved the crowd to love him even more.
v. [withered; withered; withering] wilt; shrivel E.G. The plant withered slowly since it received little light and little water.
adj. shriveled; withered E.G. The wizened face of the old man was covered by his hat.
adj. to be expressionless or dull E.G. The wooden expression of the man made him look like a statue.
adj. commonplace E.G. The workaday meal was not exciting to the world class chef.
n. violent or unrestrained anger; fury E.G. Do not trespass on his property or you will have to deal with his wrath.
v. [wreaked; wreaked; wreaking] to give vent; to inflict E.G. The dragon will wreak havoc upon the countryside.
v. [wrested; wrested; wresting] to pull or force away by a violent twisting E.G. The warriors wrest the power from the king.
adj. miserable or unhappy; causing distress E.G. Brought up in an orphanage, Annie led a wretched existence. The continual rain made for a wretched vacation.
adj. [wrier, wryer; wriest, wryest] mocking; cynical E.G. He has a wry sense of humor which sometimes hurts people's feelings.
n. fear of foreigners E.G. Xenophobia kept the townspeople from encouraging any immigrants to move into the neighborhood.
n. [yokes, yoke] harness; collar E.G. The jockey led her horse by the yoke around its neck and face.
n. former period of time E.G. When he sees his childhood friends, they speak about the days of yore.
n. believer; enthusiast E.G. The zealot followed whatever rules the cult leader set.

n. [zeniths] point directly overhead in the sky; highest point E.G. The astronomer pointed her telescope straight up toward the zenith. The Broncos seemed to be at the zenith of their power just as their rivals on the turf were flagging. The sun will reach its zenith at noon. The zenith of her career occurred during her time as chairperson.
n. [zephyrs] a gentle wind; breeze E.G. It was a beautiful day, with a zephyr blowing in from the sea. The zephyr blew the boat slowly across the lake.
